loans.name: Kiganda B Group

texts.en:
The group has been together for five months. Faith sells matooke in the market. Florence, Teopista and Christine all sell raw foods and want to use the loan to buy additional food to sell. Revecate owns a kiosk.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Issam

texts.en: Issam is a 48 year old man who lives with his family in south Lebanon, in the region of Tyre. Issam has 3 children and owns an internet cafe. He is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua to buy more computers. Issam started with one computer and is constantly striving to develop his business, which is in high demand in the area.

loans.use: To buy computers

loans.name: Maher

texts.en: Maher owns a cafe in the south of Lebanon, in the region of Tyre. Maher is a 33 year old married man with 2 children. He needs a loan for the maintenance of his business and for purchasing new equipment. The surrounding inhabitants are good clients of the cafe.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and stock

loans.name: Kiganda C Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for five months. Jalia has a hardware shop. With the extra business profits, she intends to open up another hardware shop. Hellen sells vegetables in the market. Aisha sells firewood while Grace sells fish for a living.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To invest in their businesses

loans.name: Kiganda C Group

texts.en: This group has been together for five months. Jalia has a hardware shop. With the extra business profits, she intends to open up another hardware shop. Hellen sells vegetables in the market. Aisha sells firewood while Grace sells fish for a living.

loans.use: To invest in the hardware business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 61 year old married man. He lives with his wife and 2 children in south Lebanon, in the region of Tyre. Ali breeds orchids for a living. He needs a loan to purchase agricultural equipment. With the revenue he is able to generate, Ali intends to make repairs to his house.

loans.use: To buy agricultural equipment

loans.name: Kiganda D Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 30 years old and married with two children. She sells groceries. She wants to use the extra profits to start up a poultry business. Suzan and Monica both sell raw fods. Stella has a retail shop while Nululati sells fruits and vegetables.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To add in stock to their businesses.

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en: Saleh is a 35 year old married man. He lives in south Lebanon, in the region of Tyre. Saleh has 4 childre and is a paving specialist. Saleh is a very reputable and respectable man. This is the first time Saleh is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua. He needs to buy material for his business in order to generate enough revenue to conduct repairs on his home.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Alindi

texts.en: Alindi is a 37 year old married man. He lives in south Lebanon, in the region of Tyre. Alindi has 2 children. Alindi sells vegetables around the region and uses his pick up truck for transportation. Alindi is a popular young man in his village and in the neighboring surroundings. He needs a loan to help him replace his pick up truck.

loans.use: To replace his pick up truck

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 45 year old married man. He lives in south Lebanon, in the region of Tyre. Ali has 4 children. Ali used to be in the education sector for many years and now performs stone work. He needs a loan to buy material for his business. He will use the income he generates from his business to pay for the maintenance of his house.

loans.use: To buy construction material

loans.name: Acholi A Group

texts.en:
Alice is 36 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a driver. All of her children are in school.  Alice usually earns uganda shs.15000 profits weekly.  With the extra profits for the business, Alice wants to buy more land for stone quarrying. 
Scovia wants to use the loan to purchase more charcoal for sale.  Florence is a poultry farmer and wants to buy poultry feed with the loan. Hasifah sells fish while Getu sells fruits and vegetables.
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To re-invest in their businesses.

loans.name: Madinah

texts.en: “I am a fashion lady and love to see people look good.” This was N.’s response when she was asked why she chose to venture into business of selling shoes, ladies' wear, and men’s wear. N. is 49 years old; she is married and has five children with four dependents. She operates a general store in Lugazi town; she has run this business for the last 14 years. She has received and paid back loans for over 8 years. She joined a lending group and received a loan of $30, which she repaid on schedule. Because of her excellent record, she was given subsequent loans. She has repaid loans amounting to $2950. Her business has grown, and she has almost finished construction on a commercial building in Lugazi Town.

loans.use: Namusisi wants to buy cement, sand, and gravel to be used on her commercial building.

loans.name: Maria Carlos

texts.pt:
Maria M. is not officially married, but lives with a man with whom she has nine children. Maria’s oldest children have already started their own families, but the youngest still live with the couple. Maria and her family live in the town of Chibuto, which is the government seat of Chibuto district, in Bairro 3. Maria’s business is experiencing the same growth as when it started. She has already begun the process of bringing electric power into her residence. This is one of the positive changes occurring in her life. The loan that she received was of much help to her. She was able to increase the number of goats that she has bought.

Sales went very well once the Christmas and New Years holidays began. She sold almost all of the goats that she bought. Maria M. travels two times a month to another district where she purchases goats from the breeders. She buys each goat for 250 MT and sells each for 600 or 700, depending on size. Thus, profit is approximately 350 MT per goat, not including transportation costs.

Maria’s husband unfortunately is unemployed. She does odd jobs and works on the family farm to support her family. Maria is very satisfied with the loan that she received previously. She had requested a 3-month loan, and now would like to request another. She was able to repay the first loan on time, and without problems.

Translated from Portuguese by Steve Fogel, Kiva volunteer

Maria M. nao esta casada oficialmente, mas vive com um homem com quem tem 9 filhos. Os filhos mnais velhos de Maria ja constituiram suas prorpias familias. Mas os mais novos ainda vivem com o casal. Maria e sua famiia vivem na vila de Chibuto, Sede do distrito com o mesmo nome no Bairro 3.O negocio de Maria esta a crescer comparativamente com os primeiros tempos. Ela ja iniciou o processo de montagem de uma instalacao electrica na sua residencia. Portanto esta e uma das mudancas positivas que estao acontecendo em sua vida.O emprestimo que ela recebeu ajudou-a muito. Ela conseguiu aumentar a quantidade de cabritos que tem comprado. A venda correu-lhe muito bem uma vez que concidiu com o periodo das festa do natal e do fim do ano. Portanto ela vendeu quase todos os cabritos que comprara. Maria M. viaja 2 vezes por mes para um outro distrito onde compra os cabritos aos criadores para a revenda. cada cabrito ela tem comprado por 250,00 Mt e ela revend-/o por 600, 700 consoante o tamanho. Portanto o lucro e de aproximadamente 350 Mt por cabrito deduzindo-se o valor do transporte. O marido de Maria infelizmente nao esta empregado. Ela faz pequenos expedientes e trabalha na machamba familiar para o sustento de sua familia. Mqaria esta muito satisfeita com o emprestimo anterior recebido. Ela tinha pedido por 3 meses e agora ela quer pedir um novo . O primeiro ela consguiu fechar sem problemas nenhuns. Ela pagou pontualmente.

loans.use: To purchase more goats for resale

loans.name: Atugamile's Molemo Group

texts.en:
Atugamile, age 45, is married with 4 children (ages 12, 15, 21, and 25). She owns a shop which she started in 2004. She sells a variety of general items there from 5am to 6pm daily. The shop brings her a monthly profit of about $60.

Atugamile has taken a loan from BRAC Tanzania in the past to buy more inventory for her shop. She now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her subgroup who have businesses dealing in food sales.

loans.use: To buy shop inventory

loans.name: Easther

texts.en: Easther J. lives and works in a neighborhood in Dar es Salaam called Keko. She runs a small cafe there and sells various dishes and snacks throughout the day. She is now hoping for a loan to increase her food sales. She has received a loan from BRAC Tanzania before and this helped her business. She belongs to the loan group called Mafamikio.

loans.use: To buy food items for the cafe

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila, age 40, is divorced and takes care of her 3 children (between ages 9 and 19). She has a business of selling clothing on the street. She started doing this business in 1986 and now can make a monthly profit of about $270 from her sales. She works from 7am to 3pm daily.

Jamila hopes for a loan to buy more inventory to sell. She belongs to the loan group Kisiwani, which totals 41 members.

loans.use: To buy clothing inventory

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati, age 20, is single and lives with her aunt in Dar es Salaam. Since March 2007, she has been selling clothing to earn income and now makes about US$55 in monthly profit. Bahati works from 8 am to noon daily. Her customers often cannot afford to pay her up front for the clothes they buy and, instead, pay afterwards in regular installments. This payment system, however, creates difficulties for Bahati who must keep track of her customers in order to receive her payments in time.

Bahati hopes to receive a loan to increase her clothing stock. She belongs to the loan group Jipemoyo.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing inventory

loans.name: Jekela

texts.en:
Jekela, age 27, is married and has a 5-year-old child. Together with her husband, she also takes care of four other relatives (ages 10, 17, 18, and 22). Since 2003, Jekela has been working as a food vendor, working from 6 am to 7 pm daily and making a monthly profit of about US$185.

Jekela hopes to receive a loan to buy a larger quantity of food for sale. She belongs to the loan group Mapatano.

loans.use: Increase of food stock

loans.name: Mwanahansisi's 2026 Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Mwanahansisi, age 28, is married and has three children (all between the ages of 1 and 10). Together with her husband, she also takes care of her two sisters-in-law.

Mwanahansisi runs a clothing sales business which she started in 2006. She works from 8 am to noon daily, and this work brings in a monthly profit of about US$55. Mwanahansisi hopes to receive a loan to increase her clothing sales. She will share the loan with two other women who own businesses in clothing and food sales.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for sale

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is 30 years old and lives with her husband. She owns a beauty salon which she opened in 2002. Annie works as a hairdresser there from 8 am to 9 pm daily, making about US$135 per month.

Annie hopes to receive a loan to increase the supply of her beauty salon services. She is a member of the loan group Peace, whose members help one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: Increase in the supply of parlor's services

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde F. is 37 years old, married with two, and hails from Ishashi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells clothes, weavon (hair weaving product), attachments (extensions) and is also a stylist. She has been into her business since 1987 and needs the loan of $875 to buy more weavon, attachments and clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more weavon (hair product) and attachments (extensions)

loans.name: Swaumu's Mtanzania Group

texts.en:
Swaumu, age 32, is married and has three children (ages 5, 8, and 13). She owns a fishing business which she started in 2007. Swaumu sells fish from 8 am to 6 pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about US$65.

She hopes to receive a loan to buy more fish for sale. She will share the loan with Mwantumu and Zaituni, her sub-group members who have businesses in fish and material sales.

loans.use: Purchase of fish for sale

loans.name: Acholi B Group

texts.en:
Betty is 27 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a civil servant. Betty, Jesca, Mary and Florence all have stone Quarrying businesses. With the extra business profits, Betty wants to buy a piece of land. Aminah has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy more salon equipment.
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To re-invest in their businesses.

loans.name: Chinoyen

texts.en: Chinoyen E. is 35 years old, a mother of five, and she hails from Okoko in Lagos State Nigeria. She has a computer training center. She has been in her business since 2004. She needs a loan of $875 to buy more computers and to make chairs and tables available for training students.

loans.use: To buy more computers and chairs and tables for training students

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en: Ashura, age 28, is married and has three children between the ages of 4 and 9. Since March 2007, Ashura has been running a charcoal business: she sells charcoal from 7 am to 6 pm daily and is able to earn a monthly profit of about US$110. Ashura hopes to receive a loan to increase the monthly charcoal sales volume. She belongs to the loan group Mtanzania.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia N. is married with 2 children, is 33 years old, and hails from Okoko in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells provisions. She has been in this business since 2002 and needs a loan of $1200 to enable her to change her business into a different one. "I will like to go into the sales of spices and the juice business," says Mrs. Felicia N..

loans.use: To start a spice business and buy materials for making a juice business

loans.name: Acholi C Group

texts.en:
Grace is a 45 year old widow with five children. All the children are married and working. She owns a small bar. Grace wants to use the extra business profits to buy a piece of land and build rental rooms.Robinah sells charcoal. Kasifah offers catering services. Oliver sells used clothes while Faumah sells raw foods.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To re-invest in their businesses.

loans.name: Khadija's Cafe Group

texts.en:
Khadija, age 45, is married and has five grown-up children between the ages of 20 and 30. Since 2004, Khadija has been running a small cafe where she makes and sells pancakes and donuts from 6 am to noon each day, earning a monthly profit of about US$110.

Khadija hopes to receive a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with Dugna who is a tailor.

loans.use: Purchase of food items for a cafe

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima was born in 1973. and she lives in Zukići, a small village near the town of Živinice. She is married and together with her husband runs a small farm with cows and heifers. Their monthly income is too little for  their 5-member  family. She has 3 children and they are all going to the primary school. This is her first loan with MCO WWI in the amount of  US$ 450. She is going  to buy food  for her livestock, and in that way she will try to manage not to have to sell off her animals because  the livestock is their only income source.

loans.use: Buying farm supplies

loans.name: Taye

texts.en: Taye A. is a mother of one, 28 years old, and she hails from Okoko in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells provisions and drinks and has been in this business since 2002. She needs a loan of the sum of $1200 to buy more provisions, juice and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks.

loans.name: Acholi D Group

texts.en:
Eva is 40 years old and divorced with three children. All the children are going to school. Eva, Florence and Winfred all have stone quarrying businesses.With the extra business profits, Eva wants to save money for her children's education because she wants her children to have good quality education. Lamulasi has a retail shop and intends to use th loan to purchase more products.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more land for stone quarrying

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is 35 years old, married, and has three children (ages 4, 5, and 13). Together with her husband, she also takes care of a 16- and a 17-year-old. Zainab owns a shop where she sells general items from 7 am to 9 pm daily. She started the business in 2000 and now makes a monthly profit of about US$280.

Zainab hopes to receive a loan to buy more stock for her shop. She is a member of the loan group Jikwamue 1.

loans.use: Increase the stock of a general store

loans.name: Olujoke

texts.en: Olujoke S. is married with 3 children, is 32 years old, and hails from Ajamgbadi area in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a stylist and sells weavon (a hair weaving product) and attachments (extensions). She has been in LAPO as a secretary of a union since 2005. She needs a loan of $450 to buy more weavon and relaxer for sale.

loans.use: To buy more weavon and hair relaxer.

loans.name: Chinwendu

texts.en: Chinwendu U. is a married women, 27 years old, and she comes from Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food and drinks. She has been in this business since the year 2005 and needs $450 to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Fatma's Hekima Group

texts.en:
Fatma, age 40, is divorced and lives with her 7-year-old daughter. She also has three other children, including twins. Since 2005, Fatma has been making a living selling clothing and soft drinks on the street. She works from 8 am to 4 pm daily and makes a monthly profit of about US$430.

Fatma hopes to receive a loan to increase the sales volume. She will share this loan with another loan group member, Rukia, who is a food vendor in the same locality.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and soft drinks for sale

loans.name: Peculiar

texts.en: Peculiar O. is married with 4 children, is 42 years old and comes from Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and has been in her business since 2003. She need a loan of $450 to enable her buy more foodstuffs for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Amina's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Amina, age 24, is a widow and takes care of her two children who are 8 and 5 years old. She owns a clothing sales business which she started in 2007. Amina works from 8 am to 4 pm daily and makes a monthly profit of about US$40.

Amina hopes to receive a loan to buy more clothing for sale. She will share this loan two other women who have businesses in charcoal and food sales.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for sale

loans.name: Acholi E Group

texts.en:
Aisha is 36 years old and married with seven children. The husband is a business man. She has a stone quarrying business. She usually earns shs. 80,000 profits each week. Aisha believs that if she is given another chance to borrow, she can be able to employ other people for maximum output. Harriet has a charcoal selling business. Goretti sells used clothes and wants to use the loan to add to her stock. Betty works in a bar.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more land for stone quarrying

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en: Bumi A. is a mother of 4 and is 42 years old; she lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been a member of LAPO for the past 2 years. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. She has been in business since 1992. She needs the loan of $450 to buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Hawa's Tujikomboke Group

texts.en:
Hawa, age 41, is married and has five children (23, 21, 17, 14, and 11 years old). Together with her husband, she also takes care of her 80-year-old father. Hawa is a food vendor and works from 7am to 3 pm daily, making and selling food dishes and snacks. She started this business in 2006 and now makes a monthly profit of about US$90.

Hawa is asking for a loan in order to be able to increase her sales. She will share the loan with three other businesswomen who earn income selling food, timber, and poultry.

loans.use: Purchase of food items for sale

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann A. is married with 5 children, is 30 years of age and hails from Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells fried chicken and turkey. She has been with LAPO as a client for the past 2 years. She has been in her business since the year 2002 and seeks a loan of $450 to buy more chicken and turkey for sale.

loans.use: To buy more chicken and turkey for sale

loans.name: Acholi F Group

texts.en:
Carol is 32 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a teacher. She has a beauty salon business. Carol wants her children to become teachers like their father. With the extra business profits, she wants to buy a piece of land. Rosemary and E. both have stone quarrying businesses and want to use the loan to expand them. Annet sells charcoal and wants to purchase more charcoal to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more salon equipment.

loans.name: Salama's Tjikomboe Group

texts.en:
Salama, age 27, is married and has two children (ages 10 and 4). Together with her husband, she also takes care of her 70- and 80-year-old parents. Salama owns a snack and soap sales business which she started in 1998. She works from 7 am to 6 pm daily and makes a monthly profit of about US$110.

Salama hopes to receive a loan to increase her sales. She will share it with two other women who have businesses in food and general items sales.

loans.use: Purchase of snacks and soap for sale

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo A. is married with 5 children and she is 40 years old. She comes from Iyano in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been a client with LAPO for the past 2 years. She sells clothes and baby wear. She has been in business since the year 2002. She requests a loan of $875 to buy more clothes and baby wear for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and baby wear to be sold

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth, 45 years old, is a widow and has two children (ages 21 and 20). Since 2006, she has been making money selling bottles. Elizabeth works from 8 am to noon daily and makes a monthly profit of about US$90.

She hopes to receive a loan to buy a stock of bottles for sale. Elizabeth belongs to a loan group called Mshikamano which has a total of 40 members who help one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: Purchase of bottles for sale

loans.name: Kudirat

texts.en: Kudirat S. is a married woman and has 7 children; she is 50 years old. She hails from Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells fish and charcoal and has been in business since 1980. She hopes to get the loan of $450 to buy more fish and charcoal for sale.

loans.use: To buy more fish and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Salma's Nyota Group

texts.en:
Salma, age 49, is a widow and has four grown-up children. She takes care of her three grand-children who are 16, 11, and 5 years old. Salma is a food vendor and works from 7 am to 4 pm daily, making and selling food dishes and snacks. She started this business in 1988 and now makes a monthly profit of about US$80.

Salma is asking for a loan to increase her food sales. She will share this loan with three other women who have businesses in selling food, vegetables, and snacks.

loans.use: Increase of food stock for a grocery store

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: N. Annet is a young entrepreneur who earns a living selling charcoal and firewood. Charcoal and firewood are common sources of cooking energy in most parts of Uganda. Annet is a single mother of four and like many families in Uganda she takes care of three children of her late sister. Annet sells about 60 bags of charcoal every week and makes a net profit of about $120. This helps her to educate five children who are in primary school. She is happy the business is doing very well and has the opportunity to receive loans from PEARL Microfinance. The loan will be used for business purposes and will be utilized as planned. She plans to increase the quantity of charcoal she has by 40 bags because there is growing demand in Lugazi.

loans.use: Namakula would like to buy 40 bags of charcoal to meet the high demand.

loans.name: Kagugube A Group

texts.en:
Flavia is 40 years old, married, and has five children. Her husband is an accountant. She has a cosmetic shop. She believes that if she increases her stock, she can obtain higher profits. With the extra business profits, Flavia wants to build rental rooms so that she can save money for her childrens' education. Sylvia has a beauty salon. Mirember has a retail shop business. Sylvia's current business is growing mushrooms.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to add stock to the cosmetic shop

loans.name: Hawa's Nyota Group

texts.en:
Hawa, age 40, is married and has four children (18, 12, 9, and 2 years old). Together with her husband, she also takes care of her 25- and 20-year-old brother and sister. Hawa is a food vendor and works from 7 am to 4 pm daily, making and selling food dishes and snacks. She started this business in 2004 and now makes a monthly profit of about US$90.

Hawa hopes to receive a loan to increase her sales. She will share this loan with Amina, a member of her loan group who also earns money selling snacks in her locality.

loans.use: Increase of food stock

loans.name: Morufat

texts.en: Morufat A. is 29 years old, married with 4 children, and hails from Araromin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer and sells clothes. She has been in her business since 1999 and needs the loan of $275 to get more clothing and cloth to be sold.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma P. is 27 years old. She is a single mother of a 7 year old daughter who attends school. They live in a village called Rincon Guazu, about 5 kilometers from the urban city of Ybycui.

Norma tells us that she started her business two years ago in a rented stall in the municipal market of Ybycui, after spending years saving up her money as an employee of a similar business. She began by selling table cloths, plates and glasses among other items. Later, with her earnings, she was able to incorporate new products and today she also offers lingerie.

Norma dreams that one day she'll be able to move her business to her home so she won't have to leave her daughter at a day care center. She is requesting a loan to buy a greater variety of lingerie, so she can continue to grow her business even more.

La señora Norma P. tiene 27 años de edad es madre soltera de una hija de 7 años que cursa el primer grado de la escuela primaria. Ellas viven en un pueblo llamado Rincón Guazú, distante a 5 km. de la zona urbana de la ciudad de Ybycui.

Doña Norma nos cuenta que hace dos años abrió su negocio en uno de los salones del mercado municipal de Ybycuí que ella alquila, luego de pasar años ahorrando en su trabajo como empleada de un negocio similar. Norma cuenta que empezó vendiendo cubiertos, platos, vasos, jarras entre otras cosas; luego con las ganancias fue incorporando nuevos productos y hoy día también vende ropa interior y bijouterie.

Sueña que algún día pueda mudar su negocio a su casa para no dejar a su hija, pues la niña queda todo el día al cuidado de una niñera. Solicita el préstamo para poder comprar mayor variedad de ropa interior, y así ir ampliando cada vez más el negocio.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE MERCHANDISE SO SHE CAN CONTINUE TO GROW HER BUSINESS.  HER GOAL IS TO BE ABLE TO MOVE HER BUSINESS TO HER HOME, SO SHE DOESN'T HAVE TO LEAVE HER YOUNG DAUGHTER IN DAY CARE ALL THE TIME.

loans.name: Mufuli

texts.en: Mufuli M. is  30 years old, married and has 3 children. she lives in Araronin in lagos State, Nigeria. She sells cloths. she has been in business since 2000.  She isrequesting for a loan of $275 to buy more cloths for sale. she thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more cloths for sale

loans.name: Kagugube B Group

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old, divorced and has three children. The children are all at school. She wants to use her extra business profits to open up another salon. Harriet has a stone quarrying business. Adronica grows flowers to sell while Sarah is a poultry farmer.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to buy more hairdryers

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is 39 years old and married. She financially supports her 59-year-old mother and earns money selling clothing and snacks. Zainab started this business in 1989. Every day, she works from 7 am to 4 pm and is able to make a monthly profit of about US$110.

Zainab would like to take out a loan to buy more items for sale. She is a member of the loan group Tuimarike which has a total of 33 members who help each other in paying back their loans.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for sale

loans.name: Kagugube C Group

texts.en:
Rose is 34 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a business man. Rose has a drug store. With the extra profits, she intends to start up a clinic with matenity section. She usually earns shs. 60, 000 profits each week. Catherine, Jenifer and Aisha all have retail shop business. Winnie owns a beauty salon.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs

loans.name: Sauda's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Sauda, age 30, is married and takes care of her 70-year-old mother. Sauda owns a banana sales business which she started in 2007. She works from 5 am to 6 pm daily and makes a monthly profit of about US$180 from her sales.

Sauda hopes to receive a loan to buy a stock of bananas for sale. She will share this loan with two other women who have businesses in clothing and food sales.

loans.use: Purchase of fruit for sale

loans.name: Tawa-Kalitu

texts.en: Tawa-Kalitu O. is 34 years old, married with a child, and she hails from Araromin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer with 6 tailoring machines and 5 apprentices. She also sells tailoring materials. She has been in business for past 5 years. She seeks for a loan of $275 to buy more cloth and tailoring material for sale.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials for sale.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah O. is 33 years old, married with 3 children, and hails from Araromin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks, and she has been in her business since 2003 and needs the loan of $275 to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Rfppn Group

texts.fr:
Following this year ‘s lack of rain, the Women’s Group of Popenguine for the Protection of the Environment has decided to create a cereal bank to prepare for the next few months, because the crops are not good. This is why, for the first time, we are asking for financing so we can buy peanuts, millet, corn and baobab fruits to stock those products.  At this time, we would like to take advantage of the marketing drive to buy the maximum amount of grain possible, because we know the danger of famine is likely to be felt this year and surely the winter will be tough. This is how we will be able to supply the population of our ecovillage in foodstuff. Thus, our advanced planning will serve the population of the ecovillage.
Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Suite à une pluviomètrie déficiente pour cette année, le Regroupement des Femmes de Popenguine pour la 

Protection de la Nature a décidé  de créer une banque de céréales pour préparer les prochains mois, car 

les récoltes ne sont pas bonnes. C'est pour cela que pour la première fois nous demandons un 

financement afin de pouvoir acheter des arachides, du mil, du maîs et des fruits de baobab pour stocker ces 

produits. En ce moment, nous voulons profiter de la campagne de commercialisation pour achater le 

maximum possible de grains, car nous savons que la famine risque de se faire sentir cette année et que 

certainement la période hivernale va être très dure. Ce qui fait que nous pourrons venir fournir les 

populations de notre écovillage en denrée alimentaire. Ainsi, la prévision que nous aurons fait servira à la   

population de  l'écovillage

loans.use:
Purchase of cereals to constitute a bank of stock.
Achat de céréales pour constituer une banque de stock

loans.name: Babile's Muamku Group

texts.en:
Babile, age 39, is single and takes care of her two children (ages 20 and 16). She is a food vendor and works from 5 am to 4 pm daily, making and selling various food dishes and snacks. Babile also sells clothes on the side. She started this business in 2005 and now makes a monthly profit of about US$170 from her sales.

Babile hopes to receive a loan to purchase more food items for sale. She will share this loan with a group of other women who have businesses in tailoring, as well as clothing, food, and fabric sales.

loans.use: Purchase of food items

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia V. is a young single woman who lives at home with her parents. Although she has no children of her own, she works everyday with the youth of Luque as an elementary school teacher. Cynthia’s dream was to one day own her own business and after hard work she has now obtained it.

A few years ago, Cynthia opened a women’s clothing store in her house. Because she lacked the initial capital to open it on her own, she had partners who shared in the expenses. Time passed and the business grew. Soon Cynthia was able to buy out her partners and continue selling clothes on her own.

Today, she has a small business with one of the best reputations in town along with a number of dedicated clients. Cynthia’s hope is to continue growing her business and move it out of her house and into the center of the city. With the profits she makes from her business, she plans to then attend the university and gain a business degree.

With this loan, she will increase her stock of merchandise, buying more pants, shirts, undergarments, sandals, and shoes to provide for the women of Luque.

loans.use: To buy female undergarments, pants for women, shirts, sandals, and women’s outfits.

loans.name: Lawal

texts.en: Lawal Riskat is 42 years old, married with 6 children and hails from Shibiri in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks, provisions, foodstuffs and has a grinding machine for tomatoes and peppers. She has been a LAPO client for the past 3 years. She is requesting for a loan of $275 to buy more drinks, provision and foodstuffs for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, provisions, foodstuffs and a grinding machine.

loans.name: Fredy

texts.en: Fredy Mendoza is a 27-year-old father of two children who lives in a populated neighborhood in the town of Luque.  As a single father, Fredy has been dedicated to recycling all types of paper and cardboard, and afterwards, selling them to local businesses.  He has done this for five years now in order to support his family.  Today he is applying for a loan in order to buy a great quantity of papers, thereby increasing his quantity of clients, hence increasing his sales.

loans.use: To buy paper and carboard.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret K. is married with 6 children, is 50 years old and hails from Shibiri in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells charcoal in her community. She has been in business since 2003 and has been a client of LAPO for the past 2 years. She needs the loan of $275 to buy more charcoal to be sold.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Nabi

texts.en: H. Nabi is a 40-year-old trader whose small food store is located in a  village in the Imishli region.   He has five years of experience in this field. He is married and has three children. He has applied for 1200 USD  in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Amudat

texts.en: Amudat A. is 45 years old, married with 7 children, and hails from Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells tailoring materials; she has been in business since 2005 and needs a loan of $275 to buy more tailoring materials for sale. She thanks you!

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Jam Bougoum Group

texts.fr:
We are a village of almost 400 people who are fishermen and farmers. Our area enjoys a flood-retarding basin that allows us from now on to cultivate the land year round. Since we live around the basin, we would like to take advantage of the water’s proximity to generate and commercialize market gardening produce that are farmed all around. The financing will be used to buy watering cans, gardening tool, seeds, fertilizers and pesticides. We will also buy what others produce to go and sell them in Mbour, a big town and a seaside town full of hotels. The population wants to take advantage of the proximity of the basin to really fight poverty.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Nous sommes un village de près de 400 habitants qui sont des pêcheurs et agriculteurs. Notre zone bénéficie d'un bassin de rétention qui nous permet désormais de faire de l'agriculture durant toute l'année. Puisque nous habitons autour du bassin, nous voulons profiter de la proximité de l'eau pour faire de la production et la commercialisation de des produits maraîchers qui se cultivent tout autour. Le financement nous servira à nous équiper en arrosoirs, matériels de jardinage, semences, engrais et pesticides et aussi à acheter ce que les autres personnes produisent pour aller les vendre à Mbour qui une station balnéaire plein d'hôtels et qui est une très grande ville. les population veulent profiter de la proximité du bassin pour vraiment lutter contre la pauvreté.

loans.use:
Purchase of seeds and other market gardening tools. Purchase of produce for resale.

Achat de semences et autres matériels de maraîchage. Achat de produits maraîchers pour revendre.

loans.name: Musharraf

texts.en: H. Musharraf is a 47-year-old woman who sells dairy products to the local bazaar traders and the local people. She has seven years of experience in this field. She lives with her husband and three children in the IDP camp in the Saatli region. Breeding cows is the only  source of  income, and she tries very hard to meet her family's needs. Her present income is not enough to expand her current business, which she would like to do by purchasing two cows for an estimated cost 500 USD per cow (1,000 USD total).

loans.use: To purchase two cows

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: A. Toyin is married with 4 children, is 34 years old and hails from Shibiri in Lagos State, Nigeria; she sells baby wear and shoes. She has been in her business since 2002 and needs a loan of $275 to buy more baby wear and shoes for sale. She has been a client of LAPO for the past 2 years.

loans.use: To buy more baby clothing and shoes to sell

loans.name: Ferzaga

texts.en: N. Ferzaga is a 54-year-old man who breeds cattle for meat production. He has bred and sold them to the local bazaar traders for four years. Meat is very popular, being eaten almost everyday throughout Azerbaijan. Ferzaga is married with three children, and because his income does not cover his family's needs, he has applied for 1200 USD to purchase three calves at an estimated cost of 300 USD each, with the remaining money to be used for the purchase of fodder.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Romoke

texts.en: "LAPO has been a source of financial strength to my business," says Mrs. Romoke O., who lives in Shibiri in Lagos State, Nigeria. A mother of 4, 35 years old, she sells foodstuffs and has been in business since 1999. She needs a loan of $450 to buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mondinotu

texts.en: Mondinotu A. is married with 3 children, is 35 years old and hails from Itire in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and she has been in her business since 1995. She has been with LAPO as client for the past 3 years and needs a loan of $275 to buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Qayit

texts.en: A. Qayit is  a 39-year-old trader who owns a store in  a small village of the  Imishli region. She sells food, tinned goods, juices and a variety of dishes. She has seven years of experience in this business. She is married and has three children. Her husband can’t find a job and has not worked for a long time, so income from this store is the only  support for her family. She decided to expand the number of products she sells in order to  increase her income.

loans.use: To increase the number of products offered.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia E. is thirty-nine years old and married to Elías Servín, a cameraman at a local television station. Together they have two children and live in their own house.

Since childhood she has devoted herself to working laboriously to create a better life for herself. She began her career as a seamstress with her aunt. However, soon she wished to venture out on her own. After meeting her husband, Elías, she was able to become an independent businesswoman. Together they own their own party decoration business.

Today, Antonia works as a party decorator in her shop. She helps in the fight against poverty by giving jobs to other poor people in her neighborhood. What started as a struggle to improve her own situation in life, has now grown to also providing for her husband and two children. Her dream is to give her children a great childhood and help them grow into intelligent and hardworking adults. She wishes to expand her decorating business and asks for a loan to buy linens, fake flowers, glue, Styrofoam, and other decorating materials.

loans.use: To buy linen, artificial flowers, glue, Styrofoam, etc.

loans.name: Armando

texts.es:
Armando sells milk and is also starting to sell pork. He learned this business from his father who has a lot of experience in this area. The whole family is dedicated to this business and it's their main source of income. As the oldest brother in the family, Armando helps with the household costs. They live in the community of Ninachiri - Laja, located about an hour and a half from La Paz. The loan will be used to buy a dairy cow, in order to increase the quantity of milk they can sell to the dairy factory. This is his first loan with Impro and the evaluation shows that he is qualified to receive the credit.

Armando es productor de leche y se esta iniciando como comerciante de carne de cerdo; estas actividades han sido transmitidas por su padre, quien tiene bastante experiencia en los rubros. Actualmente toda la familia se dedica a estas actividades y es su principal fuente de ingreso. Armando es el hermano mayor de la familia y colabora con los gastos del hogar, vive en la Comunidad de Ninachiri – Laja (Ubicado a una hora y media de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito requiere para comprar una vaca lechera de mediana calidad y forraje, para incrementar la cantidad de leche que vende a PIL Andina (fábrica de productos lácteos). Es el primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación que se realizó permite aprobarle el préstamo solicitado.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO BUY A DAIRY COW FOR THE FAMILY BUSINESS

loans.name: Ruben

texts.es:
Ruben has a business offering a taxi service between the city of El Alto and La Paz. His wife makes handicrafts such as blankets and coats. This work provides the main source of income for their family and the care of their two young sons. They live in the zone called Pasankeri in the city of La Paz. They need the loan for the maintenance of the taxi, so Ruben's business will continue to contribute to the economic well being of the family. This is the first loan with Impro, and the evaluation shows that he is qualified to receive the credit and repay the loan.

Rubén tiene su Taxi que trabaja de transporte público Inter-ciudad El Alto – La Paz; él trabaja de chofer y su esposa es artesana y confecciona chamarras y abrigos, constituyéndose estas actividades en sus principales ingresos con los que cubren la manutención de sus dos pequeños hijos; vive en la Zona de Pasankeri de la Ciudad de La Paz. El crédito requiere para el mantenimiento de su taxi para seguir contribuyendo económicamente a las necesidades de la familia. Es el primer crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada le faculta para aprobar la solicitud que realizo Rubén.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: THE LOAN WILL BE USED FOR NECESSARY MAINTENANCE ON HIS TAXI, WHICH HE USES TO PROVIDE A SERVICE BETWEEN THE CITIES OF EL ALTO AND LA PAZ.  HE AND HIS WIFE BOTH WORK TO SUPPORT THEIR TWO YOUNG SONS.

loans.name: Constancia

texts.en:
Constancia M. is a 64-year-old woman whose husband, Carlos M., passed away two years ago.  Together, they had two sons who have both become educators, and who both live with her to offer support and help.  
In order to survive financially, Constancia decided to open a small commercial business for everyday goods.  With the help of her sons, Constancia’s store has receive much approval and has grown into a beautiful little grocery store; the only one in the neighborhood. 
Constancia is asking for a loan so that she may buy sugar, oil, yerba, refreshments like beer and soda, dairy products, assorted breads and more.  This will enable her and her sons to continue expanding their business, their sales, and consequently their incomes.

loans.use: To buy merchandise like sugar, oil, yerba, beer, soda, and    dairy.

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.es:
Eugenio has a minibus and offers his customers a transportation service between the cities of El Alto and La Paz. His wife makes knitted handicrafts. These businesses provide the main source of income for their family and the care of their 4 young children. They live in the zone called Pedro Domingo Murillo - in the city of El Alto. They need the loan for necessary maintenance on the minibus, so Eugenio can continue to contribute to the economic well being of the family. This is his first loan with Kiva, and the evaluation shows he qualifies to receive and repay the credit.

Eugenio tiene su minibús que trabaja de transporte público Inter ciudad El Alto – La Paz; él trabaja de chofer y la esposa realiza tejidos de chompas para cholitas. Estas actividades son la fuente de sus principales ingresos con los que cubren la manutención de sus cuatro pequeños hijos; vive en la Zona Pedro Domingo Murillo – Rio Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito requiere para el mantenimiento de su minibús para seguir contribuyendo económicamente con la familia. Es el primer crédito con kiva, la evaluación realizada le faculta para aprobar la solicitud que realizo Eugenio.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: THE LOAN WILL BE USED FOR MAINTENANCE ON HIS MINIBUS.   HIS TRANSPORTATION BUSINESS BETWEEN THE CITIES OF EL ALTO AND LA PAZ  IS THE MAIN SOURCE OF INCOME TO PROVIDE FOR HIS 4 YOUNG CHILDREN.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo R. is 34 years old, and has been married to Teodora Fretes for twelve years. They have two small children, eleven-year-old Raquel and five-year-old Mercedes.

Since the age of fourteen, Alfredo has worked in the blacksmith business and has been employed by different companies. After gaining much experience and some savings, Alfredo opened up his own humble business. He has been working independently now for 12 years in his business called “Ingá.”

With the increase of demand, Alfredo had to take out a loan from Fundación Paraguaya to buy more tools and build a small warehouse.

Currently, he has three employees and innumerable work requests. With a loan Alfredo will expand his workshop so that he may continue to increase the size of his company, hire more employees, and fulfill the work requests he is receiving. Alfredo’s business is not only allowing him to become economically self sufficient, it is also giving jobs to people in the town.

loans.use: To buy pipes, rods, wheel spokes, locks, etc.

loans.name: Amado

texts.en:
Amado Ramon O. is 58 years old and the son of merchants. He and his wife Asuncion have a twenty-four-year-old daughter. As the son of merchants, Amado was taught from an early age how to be a successful businessman.

When Amado was 25 years old, his parents gave him a gift of some capital to begin a business of his own. After seeing that there was a demand for construction materials and general hardware equipment, Amado decided to open his own hardware store. With the money given to him by his parents, he bought some construction materials and hardware and opened the store from his house. With the accumulated profits from selling hardware, he and his wife added a small convenience store to their business which she runs that on a daily basis.

Both stores, the hardware and convenience store bring in small amounts of income, however his goal is to continuously expand the business. Amado and his family are an enthusiastic group of people with a knack for business.

With a loan, he will only continue to diversify the goods sold in the convenience store and buy popular items like Yerba, sugar, cooking oil, and drinks like beer, soda, water and wine. Eventually, as his business continues to grow, he hopes to buy a truck to start a delivery business from his store. With a delivery system, he is expanding his clientele, having the ability to take large, bulky items to houses that don’t have access to a car.

loans.use: To buy Yerba, sugar, oil, and drinks.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
From the age of 10, Maria Elena has worked selling used clothing in the market of Leon. She began her business selling small quantities, and as the years passed, she has been acquiring greater quantities to sell. Her husband's income was not enough to cover their household costs, so Maria Elena decided to invest in her own business. Over the years, they've had 2 children and so their responsibilities have grown and they have to work even harder to care for their children and their modest home. The unconditional support of Ceprodel the last two years has provided 18 credits which they've used to purchase more products to sell and better support their home.

Maria Elena desde hace 10 años se dedica al negocio de venta de ropa usada en un tramo del mercado la Estación en León. Su negocio lo inició vendiendo en pequeñas cantidades sus productos pero por medio de los años ha venido adquiriendo mas cantidades para su debida comercialización.

El negocio lo comienza por la necesidad que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado su familia, el cual los ingresos de su esposo no daban abasto para los gastos del hogar, es por esto que decide invertir en este negocio. Con el paso de los años, nacieron sus ds hijos y su responsabilidad proliferó ya que le es necesario trabajar mas fuertemente para que junto con su esposo mantengan a sus hijos, y a la vez las mismas necesidades de su humilde hogar.

Su apoyo incondicional ha sido Ceprodel desde hace 2 años atrás brindándole un total de 18 créditos utilizados para la adquisición de sus productos y a la vez para el sustento de su hogar.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE MERCHANDISE FOR HER USED CLOTHING BUSINESS.  THIS BUSINESS PROVIDES THE NECESSARY INCOME TO HELP SUPPORT HER HOME AND 2 YOUNG CHILDREN.

loans.name: Augusto

texts.en:
Augusto and Melva B. are self-made entrepreneurs who own a simple convenience store in their town of Ciudad del Este. They have three children who are all older and who live and work outside the house.

Seven years ago, Augusto and his wife opened their store with the help of their eldest son. To help manage the store, Melva learned to balance her time between domestic work and store work. They wish to continue being self sufficient and not depend on their sons for financial help.

Their plans are to continue growing their business, however they need the help of a loan to buy goods like sugar, flour, cooking oil, cleaning products, and drinks. Augusto and Melva are dynamic individuals who are committed to always working towards a brighter future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, flour, noodles, cooking oil, other foods and household products.

loans.name: Porfiria

texts.en:
Porfirio Patino is a 61-year-old woman who is married to Enriques Amarilla, a mason and bricklayer. His work helps with the income and covers the house expenses; however, his work alone was not enough to raise their two children. Porfiria took the initiative to begin her own business so that she too could earn money to raise her children. Together she and husband created a business plan and used some of her husband’s earnings to establish a simple grocery store with the basic necessities.

Since it was located in a neighborhood which lacked a grocery store, it began to grow. Today it is called Porfi’s Grocery and through great efforts it is now a profitable business venture, one which helped provide for their children. It is still the only grocery shop in the area and they have gained a great amount of clients.

Thanks to Porfirio’s dedication, the earnings of the shop have allowed her two children to attend high school. Porfirio and her husband have an image of what their children’s future should be and hope that they will also work hard and invest wisely. Porfirio is asking for a loan to invest in the shop. Merchandise like oil, sugar, flour, pasta, along with assorted breads and dairy products are needed to keep the business and their income growing.

loans.use: To buy goods such as oil, breads, pasta, flour, etc.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto Riva is a young 28-year-old man who lives with his wife Nélida Ovando and their child.  Since a young age, Roberto has worked arduously to improve his condition in life.  He began as a traveling salesman, and it was during this time he met his wife.  They worked hard and soon saved enough capital to create their own small business.  Now, with a wife and a child to support, Roberto must work even harder to provide for his family.

Roberto’s business has continued to grow and now gives work to other people in the neighborhood.  He sells various things at their store including clothing and household goods. Roberto is asking for a loan in order to buy more jeans and shirts, bedding, cooking pans, grills, and thermoses.  The Riva’s plan is to continue expanding their business and provide a better life for their son. They hope that their son will someday become a great man and be successful in whatever profession he chooses.

loans.use: To buy jeans, shirts, thermoses, cooking pans, barbeque grills, and bed sheets.

loans.name: Eude

texts.en:
Eude V. is married to Elba Rojas and they have two sons and a daughter who is the youngest.  Eude began a small telephone business based out of his house.  Here clients may come and use one of his few telephones and pay him when they are done.  He was able to begin the business by selling a plot of his own land in 2000.  Today, his wife runs the telephone business while Eude pursues other forms of income as a traveling street vender selling pasta. 

The business is profitable for what they have but they wish to invest more into the telephone business and make renovations to the facilities.  The loan will be used to buy computers so that they can sell the services of both telephones and computers.  With the addition of the computers, Eude’s business will have a more competitive edge and also offer more convenience for his customers.  This will attract more clientele, therefore increasing profits.  In the future, Mr. and Mrs. V. hope their business continues to flourish and that they will have enough money to construct a house of their own.

The woman who appears in the picture is Eude´s wife Elba, who is the manager of the telephone business.

loans.use: To buy more computers for their telephone business.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.es:
Rosalina Perez has two businesses which she runs from the same location, one selling refreshments, (fruit juices) and the other selling every day grocery items such as soap, detergents, etc. She is a single mother of two children and is also responsible for two grandchildren. She began her business 8 years ago with an investment of $20, purchasing the ingredients to make her juices. One she secured her stall in the market to sell her refreshments, she began to expand to other products. Rosalina needs to purchase merchandise such as oil, soap, bleach, as well as fruits for her drinks. Ceprodel has helped her with 17 credits to help build her business and support her home.

La señora Rosalina P. se dedica a dos negocios en un mismo local, estos son la venta de refrescos y la venta de abarrotarías (productos varios como jabón, pastes, detergentes, etc.)

Es madre soltera y con dos hijos y dos nietos a su cargo. Su negocio nace hace 8 años con la inversión de veinte dólares para la adquisición de materia prima para elaborar sus refrescos. Una vez que obtiene su tramo en el mercado para vender los refrescos, incursiona en la venta de abarrotarías en su establecimiento. Una necesidad que posee la señora Rosalina es que necesita invertir en la compra de su mercadería como lo es aceite, jabones, pastes, cloro y también frutas para elaborar sus refrescos. Por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos que los invierte directamente en la inversión de su negocio y además en los gastos de su hogar. Su record crediticio es de 17 créditos con Ceprodel.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE MERCHANDISE FOR HER SMALL STORE,  INCLUDING COOKING OIL, BLEACH, SOAP, AS WELL AS FRUITS WHICH SHE NEEDS TO PREPARE FRESH JUICES.

loans.name: Angela Isabel

texts.es:
Angela Isabel, or "Angelita" as her friends call her, has a business selling every day grocery items such as oil, soap, detergents, shampoo, etc. She has 3 children whom she must take care of and educate. She began her business 8 years ago in the Leon station market, with money she received as a loan. After buying the first products, she began to aggressively sell them, working hard to clear her debt. She needs to invest in more stock for her business, and Ceprodel has helped her with 11 credits which she has invested to grow her business and continue to support her home.

Angela Isabel conocida comúnmente como angelita se dedica a vender productos de abarrotaría como aceite, jabón, pastes, detergentes, escobas, shampoo, etc.)

Posee tres hijos que tiene el deber de educar y brindar protección y alimentación. Su negocio da inicio desde hace 8 años en el mercado la Estación de León, con una inversión de $500 (Quinientos dólares netos) que los obtuvo por medio de un préstamo a un prestamista. Una vez que compró los primeros productos, muy esforzadamente los comercializó y busco la manera de cómo salir de esta deuda hasta acabarla.

Una necesidad que posee angelita es que necesita invertir en la compra de los abarrotes y por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos (Actualmente 11 créditos a su favos)que los invierte directamente en su negocio y de esta manera llevar el sustento a su hogar que tanto lo necesita.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MORE STOCK FOR HER BUSINESS, SUCH AS OIL, SOAP, DETERGENT, SHAMPOO, ETC.  HER BUSINESS ALLOWS HER TO CARE FOR AND EDUCATE HER THREE CHILDREN.

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.es:
Sweets, sodas and frozen drinks are a few of the products that Apolonia works hard to sell outside the market at Leon station in San Juan park. From the time she was young, she has always been characterized as a hardworker. All her life she worked washing and ironing clothes for people in their homes, but she realized that this business was not viable. Five years ago she decided to start her own small business.

One of her problems at her advanced age, is the need to carry all of her products from her house to the the park in order to sell them. She works hard to take care of her two young grandchildren for whom she is responsible. She is requesting a loan from Ceprodel, who has helped her with 11 previous loans over the last few years. These loans allow her to maintain her business and take care of her grandchildren.

Dulces, gaseosas y agua helada son los productos que muy esforzadamente vende la señora Apolonia en las afueras del mercado la Estacion en Leon, exactamente en el parque San Juan. Desde muy niña, esta señora se ha caracterizado por ser una excelente trabajadora. Toda su vida la ha dedicado a lavar y planchar en los diferentes hogares pero al darse cuenta de que este negocio no es rentable, hace 5 años decidió comenzar un pequeño negocio de venta de dulces, gaseosas y agua helada.

Un problema que atraviesa es que a pesar de ser de edad muy avanzada, necesita trasladar sus productos desde su casa de habitación al parque donde vende siendo esto una faena diaria por subsistir y llevar el pan de cada día a sus dos pequeños nietos a su cargo. Para esto ha solicitado apoyo financiero en Ceprodel quien le ha apoyado con créditos para la compra de sus productos y de esta manera apoyarse ella y a sus dos nietos a su cargo que tanto necesitan de un apoyo por ser menores de edad. Su record crediticio es de 11 créditos desde hace dos años.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE PRODUCTS SUCH AS SWEETS, SODAS AND INGREDIENTS TO MAKE FROZEN DRINKS, WHICH SHE SELLS OUTSIDE THE MARKET.  THIS BUSINESS ALLOWS HER TO CARE FOR HER TWO YOUNG GRANDCHILDREN.

loans.name: Rumanah

texts.en: Rumanah, 46, sells clothing door-to-door around the villages, earning about US$ 5 a day. Her husband, U., sells fruit and earns about US$ 15 a day. She is asking a loan of US$ 125 to add to her business capital. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her small clothing business capital

loans.name: Lili

texts.en: Lili, 37, has a small food stall. Her husband, M., is not working anymore, so to provide for her family's needs, she sells snacks and beverages at her small stall, earning about US$ 70 a month. She is requesting a loan of US$ 100 to buy more goods for her stall. As a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her stall

loans.name: Irela De La Concepci

texts.es:
Irela M. works selling clothes from her own stall inside La Estación market in the beautiful town of León, Nicaragua. M. has spent the last 16 years dedicating herself to this business.

Initially the clothes were sold in the open air from a small basket; later she obtained her own area in which she placed her products.

Ceprodel have provided Irela with financial help for the last year and a half with a total of 11 credits which have allowed her to increase her stock and ensure her children’s maintenance and continued education, thanks to the business which generates enough income in order to be able to live with dignity. She currently has a pressing need to acquire more merchandise (clothes) in order to market them, and for this reason she came to Ceprodel looking for more support.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La actividad de la señora Irela M. se refiere a la venta de ropa en un local propio dentro del mercado la Estación en la bella ciudad de León Nicaragua. La señora M. tiene 16 años de dedicarse a este negocio

Inició el negocio vendiendo la ropa a la intemperie en una canastita pequeña, luego obtiene su tramo propio donde colocar sus productos.

Ceprodel le ha brindado el apoyo financiero por un periodo de año y medio con un total de 11 créditos que le han impactado de manera que ha incrementado su mercadería y logrado la subsistencia para sus hijos que los está formando gracias al negocio que le genera utilidad para poder vivir dignamente. Su necesidad actual es la urgencia de adquirir mas mercadería (ropa) para comercializarla, es por esta razón que acude a Ceprodel buscando este apoyo.

loans.use: Buy clothes

loans.name: Angelina

texts.es:
Ms. Angelina is 48 years old, she only studied up to the fifth grade of elementary school. She has 6 children and 4 still depend on her. She lives in the district of Mache, province of Otuzco, department of La Libertad. She has been sowing grains of wheat and barley, as well as to the upbringing of some animals since she was quite young. For the past 9 years, she has been buying curd (quesillo) to sell in the city of Trujillo; she has to travels three times a week in order to do so. Ms. Angelina is a partner of the communal bank "Women of Mache", where she obtained her first loan of $100 that she use to buy 25 kilograms of curd. With the loan of $825 that she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 100 kilograms of curd and medicine for the crops. Ms. Angelina’s goal is to sow bigger quantities so she can sell the crops outside her area.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Angelina tiene 48 años de edad, estudió hasta el quinto grado de primaria. En total tiene 6 hijos y 4 aún dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Desde que era muy joven se dedicó a la siembra de granos de trigo y cebada como también a la crianza de algunos animales. Hace 9 años que se dedica a comprar cuajada (quesillo) para vender en la ciudad de Trujillo, viaja tres veces por semana para realizar dicha venta. La señora Angelina es socia del banco comunal “Mujeres de Mache”, lugar donde recibió un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, este dinero lo invirtió en comprar 25 kilogramos de cuajada. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,400.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 100 kilogramos de cuajada y medicina para la siembra. La señora Angelina tiene como objetivo sembrar en mayor cantidad para que también pueda vender la cosecha fuera de su comunidad.

loans.use: Buy curd and medicine for crops.

loans.name: Rukminah

texts.en: Rukminah, 35, is the mother of 3 children and sells flavoured ice at her house, earning about US$ 1 a day. Her husband, J., sells bags door-to-door around the villages and earns about US$ 20 a week. She is requesting a loan of US$ 75 to add to her business capital and as a member of MBK she will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Adding to her small business capital

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Ms. Julia is 49 years old, she only did the first three years of elementary school. She lives with her two children in the district of Mache, province of Otuzco, department La Libertad. She buys small animals such as guinea pigs, hens, pigs and rams, which she fattens and then she sells them in a fair that opens its doors on Sundays in the city of Julcán. She also sows wheat, barley, corn and swallows and the little that she harvests she sells it or sometimes she uses it for her own consumption. Ms. Julia belongs to the communal bank "Women of Mache", where she obtained the first loan of $100, with this money bought animals, sacks of balanced food and alfalfa. With the loan of $425, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 8 hens, 10 guinea pigs and 3 rams and balanced food for these animals. Ms. Julia Z.’s wish is to have a grocery store at home.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Julia tiene 49 años de edad, estudió hasta el tercer año de primaria. Vive en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento La Libertad, con sus dos hijos que aún dependen de ella. Ella compra animales menores (cuyes, gallinas, cerdos y carneros), los cuales los engorda por un tiempo y los vende en una feria que abre sus puertas los días domingos en Julcán, asimismo se dedica a sembrar trigo, cebada, maíz y papa y lo poco que cosecha aprovecha en venderlo o en ocasiones le sirve para su consumo. La señora Julia pertenece al banco comunal “Mujeres de Mache”, aquí obtuvo un primer préstamo S/. 300.00, con este dinero compró animales, sacos de alimento balanceado y alfalfa. Con el préstamo de S/.1,200.00, el cual pagará en 4, comprará 8 gallinas, 10 cuyes y 3 carneros y algo de alimento balanceado para estos animales. El sueño que tiene la señora Julia Z. es poner una tienda surtida en su domicilio.

loans.use: Buy chickens, guinea pigs and rams.

loans.name: Madeleyne Yanina

texts.es:
Ms. Madeleyne Yanina is 37 years old. She is a woman who works to support her 3 children who still depend on her. She only did the first graD. of elementary school and she lives in the district of Mache, Province of Otuzco, department of La Libertad. She buys curd (quesillo) from different hamlets in the district of Mache, then she sell it in the city of Trujillo. She also buys small animals as guinea pigs, hens and pigs to fatten and then sell them. She started by selling candies and sodas at her house and then she started the business of the selling curd. The first loan of $100 that she obtained from the communal bank "Women of Work", she bought candies and sodas. With the loan of $725 that she will repay in 4 months, she plans to buy a bull that will serve her help to plough the land where she has her crops and with what she has left she will buy 2 small rams. Madeleyne’s wish is to have a big number of cows to use their milk to prepare milk products.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Madeleyne Yanina tiene 37 años D. edad, es una mujer que trabaja para sacar adelante a sus 3 hijos que aún dependen D. ella. Estudió sólo el primer grado D. primaria y vive en el distrito D. Mache, Provincia D. Otuzco, departamento D. La Libertad. Ella compra cuajada (quesillo) por diferentes caseríos del distrito D. Mache para luego venderlos en la ciudad D. Trujillo, también compra animales menores como cuyes, gallinas y cerdos para engordarlos y luego venderlos. Empezó vendiendo golosinas y gaseosas en su casa y después se inició en el negocio D. la venta D. cuajada. El primer préstamo que recibió en su banco comunal “Mujeres D. Trabajo” fue D. S/. 300.00 y con este dinero compró golosinas y gaseosas. Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,100.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará un toro que le servirá D. ayuda para arar la tierra donD. tiene sus sembríos y con lo que le queda comprará 2 carneros pequeños. El sueño D. Madeleyne es tener un gran número D. vacas para aprovechar su leche y elaborar productos lácteos.

loans.use: Buy a bull and rams.

loans.name: Umdiah

texts.en: Umdiah, 37, is the mother of 3 children aged 24, 15, and 10. Her husband, J., is an employee at the airport and earns US$ 20 a week. Providing extra income for the family, she sells snacks and crispy chips, earning about US$ 5 a day. She is requesting a loan of US$ 75 to buy more goods to sell so she can increase her income for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her little stall

loans.name: Maria Jesús

texts.es:
Perishable products are all those which, in one way or another, if not used within a fixed time period, will go completely bad - up to the point where they are totally unusable. Sra. Maria de Jesús R. has specialised for the last five years in the sale of perishable goods (fruit and vegetables) in la Estación market in the town of León. One challenge for her is to sell her products quickly once she acquires them, in order to avoid them rotting and creating expense and waste for her business.

With the hope of expanding her business little by little, she asks for loans from Ceprodel who extend a friendly hand and help her. She has already managed to develop her business and obtain a slightly higher income.

The continuing work of Sra. Gonzáles provides for the upkeep of her four school-age children: that this culminates in a university course is her dearest wish, so that they are able to improve their quality of life. Her credit record is 20 credits.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Los productos perecederos son todos aquellos que de alguna u otra manera, si no se les utiliza en un determinado tiempo estos tienden a malearse por completo hasta quedar inservibles. La Sra. Maria de Jesús R. se dedica a la actividad de venta de perecederos (verduras y frutas) desde hace 5 años en el mercado la Estación de la ciudad de León. Un reto para ella es vender sus productos una vez que los adquiere, de no ser así estos se dañan y se pierden generándole gasto en su negocio.

Con la esperanza de ir progresando poco a poco en su negocio solicita préstamos a CEPRODEL quien le extiende su mano amiga y le ayuda. Hoy en día ha logrado el desarrollo de su negocio obteniendo un poco mas de ingresos.

El trabajo continuo de la Sra. Gonzáles le permite el sustento de sus cuatro hijos en edad escolar y el que coronen una carrera universitaria es su mayor sueño para que logren mejorar su nivel de vida. Su record crediticio es de 20 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase of perishable goods

loans.name: Santos Victoria

texts.es:
Ms. Santos Victoria is 49 years old, she studied until the third year of middle school. She has 6 children, but only 2 depend on her. They live in the district of Mache, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad. She has a grocery store, she also provides room and board to teachers and some students who come to study to the school of Mache. She has been able to run her grocery store, as well she has been able to run other business since she was 20 years old. Previously, she was buying wholesale curd (quesillo) to sell it and also she was buying small animals as guineas pigs and hens. A year ago she started providing room and board and she is doing really well. She belongs to the communal bank " Women of Mache ", where she obtained her first loan of $100 that invested to buy small animals to fatten them and then sell them. With the loan of $350 that she will repay in 4 months, she will buy rice, sugar, oil, noodles, etc. She will also buy the ingredients to cook for her room and board business. Ms. Santos is the president of the communal bank "Women of Mache" and she is the promoter for health for her region. Her biggest dream is to build her house in the city of Trujillo and open her business there.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Santos Victoria tiene 49 años de edad, estudió hasta el tercer año de secundaria, en total tiene 6 hijos, pero sólo 2 dependen de ella y vive en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad. Ella tiene una bodega en la que vende abarrotes, además da pensión a los profesores y a algunos alumnos que vienen de fuera a estudiar en el colegio de Mache. Desde que tenia 20 años ha mantenido su bodega como ha podido y también se ha dedicado a otros negocios. Anteriormente compraba cuajada (quesillo) al por mayor para venderlo y también compraba animales menores como cuyes y gallinas. Hace un año que empezó a dar pensión y le va muy bien. Pertenece al banco comunal “Mujeres de Mache” , lugar donde recibió un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, el cual lo invirtió comprando reses pequeñas para engordarlas y luego venderlas. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar, aceite, fideos, etc.,. Así también comprará los ingredientes para cocinar para sus pensionistas. La señora Santos es presidenta del banco comunal “Mujeres de Mache” y promotora de salud de su región. Su mayor sueño es construir su casa en la ciudad de Trujillo y ahí abrir su negocio.

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, oil, etc.

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.en: Ilgar Y. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is 44 years old, married, and has four children. He owns and operates a small car repair store in Beylagan. He started his car repair business seven years ago. He needs a loan in the amount of $475 to buy spare parts and to earn more income to improve his living. This is his first loan.

loans.use: To expand business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nuryanah

texts.en: Nuryanah, 37, is the mother of 5 children. Her husband, S., is a landless farmer, earning about US$ 80 a month.
