She has a small shop where she sells vegetables, spices, etc., earning about US$ 10 a day with a small profit. She is asking for a loan of US$ 75 to buy more goods for her shop. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her little shop

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.en: Ilgar Y. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is 42 years old, married, and has three children. He owns and operates a small spare parts store in Beylagan. He started his business seven years ago. Ilgar needs a loan in the amount of $475 to buy more kinds of spare parts and to expand his business. This is his first loan.

loans.use: To expand business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
I live with my husband and son in two very small rooms. After much sacrifice, we have been able to expand our home a little, but we had to halt construction due to lack of funds. Now, we would like to finish the expansion so that we can inhabit the rooms and as such be more comfortable. I am requesting a loan of $500.00 USD in order to finish the expansion of my house.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

“Vivo con mi esposo y mi hijo en 2 cuartos muy pequeños, con grandes sacrificios hemos logrado ampliar un poco más nuestra casa pero debido a la falta de dinero tuvimos que parar la construcción, ahora nos gustaría terminar la ampliación para poder habitar esos cuartos y así estar más cómodos”. Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para terminar la ampliación en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Finish expansion of house

loans.name: Teresa Graciela

texts.es:
Teresa Graciela is 52 years old and she studied until second graD. of Primary school. She has 4 kids who don't live with her anymore, and she lives in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzco, in the state of La Libertad.

She sells cereals such as wheat, peas and barley, which she gets during the harvest and also buys in large quantities in different ranches. She also has some machines to grind cereals to make barley flour, wheat flour and maizemeal among others. She mainly takes these products to Trujillo to sell. When she has some left over she takes advantage of this by adding some milk and making curds, and in this way she has another income.

She is a member of the group 'Women of Mache', a place where she got her first loan of $300, and with this money she bought sacks of cereal. With the loan of $2500, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy 10 sacks of wheat, 15 of barley and peas.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Teresa Graciela tiene 52 años D. edad, estudió hasta el segundo grado D. primaria, tiene cuatro hijos que ya no dependen D. ella y vive en el distrito D. Mache, provincia D. Otuzco, departamento D. La Libertad. Se dedica a la venta D. cereales tales como trigo, alverja, cebada, y chochos, los cuales adquiere D. su cosecha y también compra al por mayor en los diferentes caseríos. También posee maquinarias para moler estos cereales y elaborar harina D. alverja, morón, D. cebada, maicena, entre otras. Estos productos los lleva a vender al por mayor en la ciudad D. Trujillo. Cuando le sobra un poco D. tiempo lo aprovecha para sacar leche D. sus reses y hacer cuajada, D. esta manera tiene otro ingreso. Es socia del banco comunal “Mujeres D. Mache”, lugar donD. obtuvo un primer préstamo D. S/.300.00 y con este dinero compró sacos D. cereales. Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 10 sacos. D. trigo, 15 sacos D. cebada, alverja y chochos.

loans.use: To buy products (wheat, barley, peas) / Compra de productos (trigo, cebada, alverja)

loans.name: Mulyati

texts.en: Mulyati, 31, is the mother of 2 children. Her husband, R., does not have any job, so to earn income for her family she sells salty (pickled) eggs. Every day she processes duck eggs into salty eggs at her house then sells them at the market, earning about US$ 10 a day. She is asking for a loan of US$ 75 to expand her business and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her pickled-egg business

loans.name: Eloy

texts.es:
Eloy Q. is a gentleman who for the last seven years has had a business selling groceries in La Estación market in the department of León in Nicaragua. He is a single man who from a very young age characteristically undertook difficult and hard work such as the rearing and care of livestock: this involved tasks such as providing their food, care and undertaking manual labour in the fields with them (e.g transporting objects).

On realising that this work did not provide a stable income, he decided to begin to sell small quantities of groceries and so little by little, he was able to acquire more stock. He asked for a stall in the market and he quickly obtained, and in this way he established his business.

Despite the difficult economic situation which Eloy found himself in, he decided to take out credit with Ceprodel and use this to invest in his business. Today, after 3 years of working with Ceprodel, he has a record of 27 credits.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Eloy Q. es un caballero que desde hace 7 años se dedica al negocio de venta de abarrotes en el mercado la Estación del departamento de León en Nicaragua. Es una persona soltera que desde muy joven se caracterizó por realizar trabajos difíciles como lo es la cría y cuidado del ganado, tanto así como su alimentación, atención y trabajos del campo con ellos (traslados de artículos).

Al percibir que en este trabajo no tenia ingresos estables decide comenzar a vender pequeñas cantidades de abarrotarías y así poco a poco ir adquiriendo mas mercadería. Solicitó un tramo en el mercado y le fue entregado al instante y de esta manera es como inicia su trabajo en este negocio.

A pesar de la difícil situación económica que atraviesa el señor Eloy, decide realizar créditos en Ceprodel que los ha destinado para la inversión en su negocio. Hoy en día, con 3 años de trabajar con Ceprodel tiene un record de 27 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase groceries

loans.name: Suleyman

texts.en: Suleyman H. is 51 years old, married and has three children. He lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. Suleyman owns a small stand where he sells household products. He started his business two years ago. He applied to Normicro Beylagan Branch for a loan in the amount of $1125, and he would like to increase the size of his stand.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Nuraeni

texts.en: Nuraeni, 30, is the mother of a 6-year-old daughter. Her husband, M., does not have any job, so to earn income for the family, she sells snacks, crispy chips, etc. at her small shop and earns about US$ 15 a day. She is requesting a loan of US$ 75 to buy more goods for her shop and as a member of MBK she will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her little shop

loans.name: Rumput

texts.en: Rumput, 35, and her husband, R., are vegetable farmers. They sell their crops at the market and earn about US$ 40 a month. She is asking for a loan of US$ 125 to expand their business and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of their small vegetable farm business

loans.name: Emin

texts.en: Emin, 40, is the mother of a daughter aged 7. Her husband, S., sells recyclable materials and earns about US$ 2 a day. So to earn some extra income for the family, Emin sells snacks such as biscuits, crispy chips, etc., earning about US$ 20 a week. She needs a loan of US$ 75 to add to her small business capital and as a member of MBK she agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her small business capital

loans.name: Lina Mercedes

texts.es:
Lina C.’s business sells veterinary products and concentrates. It is located on the outskirts of la Estación market on a site frequently passed by people and motor vehicles. She began her business one and a half years ago when she stopped working in a veterinary practice because her income was too low to cover her household expenses: so she decided to market these products in order to help her partner maintain their home and their two children.

At present she needs to acquire more veterinary products and concentrates: for this reason she very wisely came to Ceprodel in order to ask for her ninth credit with this institution and thus be able to stock-up her business with products and improve her family’s quality of life.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

El negocio de la señora Lina C. es la venta de productos de veterinaria y concentrados. Se ubica en las afueras del mercado la Estación en un local muy transitado por personas y vehículos. Comienza su negocio hace un año y medio al terminar de trabajar en una veterinaria ya que sus ingresos eran muy bajos para cubrir los gastos de su hogar, decide entonces comercializar estos productos y así apoyar a su compañero de vida en el mantenimiento de su hogar y sus dos hijos.

Hoy en día su necesidad es la adquisición de los productos de veterinaria y los concentrados por lo que muy sabiamente acude a Ceprodel para realizar su noveno crédito con esta institución y de esta manera surtir su negocio de productos y mejorar el nivel de vida de su familia.

loans.use: purchase of veterinary and concentrate products

loans.name: Yasemen

texts.en: Ms. Yasemen is a 40-year-old married woman with a child. She is a farmer. She lives with her family in Saatli, situated in the central part of Azerbaijan. She started her business in 1992, when she purchased one cow with money she had saved up. The work is hard but interesting and takes a lot of effort. Yasemen purchases calves, breeds them, and sells to the butcher who works at the local big market. At the same time, the salary is not enough to cover all of her family expenses. To increase the profit margin from the selling, Yasemen has to invest some money to make her small herd bigger. She applied for $500 to buy four calves. She hopes eventually to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy calves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Nighar

texts.en: Ms. Nighar is a low-income, vulnerable woman. She is 31, married with two children, and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Nighar has a scanty herd of milk cows and sells 60 liters milk per day to the local milk processing shop and to the supermarket. The trade is good and Makhbuba can see that she could sell more milk. This requires more cattle in her herd. And Nighar decided to buy a calf to breed and hence to increase monthly turnover. She applied for a $500 loan from Normicro Saatli branch for the purpose of buying a calf and to increase the number of cattle in her herd.

loans.use: To buy a calf

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
Maria Isabel M. is a woman with many strengths who has managed to expande her clothes-selling business in the town of León in Nicaragua.

She is very proud of being a grandmother: she already has a grandson who is her responsibility and to whom she is dedicated to caring for at all times. It is for this reason that she tries to work everyday in order to give support to her young daughter in the maintenance of her small son

Through 35 long years, Maria Isabel has undertaken this activity. She used to acquire clothes sporadically but at very high prices. For this reason she came to Ceprodel in order to receive help with loans and thus acquire the merchandise to then market and sell it.

It is necessary to stress that currently she has a record of 7 credits, all repaid on time and in the correct manner. These have been used to buy stock and to improve the quality of life for her, her daughter and her grandson.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Maria Isabel M. es una dama que con muchos esfuerzos ha logrado sacar adelante su negocio de venta de ropa en la ciudad de León en Nicaragua.

Se siente muy orgullosa por ser abuela, ya que tiene un nieto a su responsabilidad que se dedica a cuidarlo en todo momento. Es por esta razón que busca la manera de trabajar todos los días por darle el apoyo a su joven hija para mantener a su pequeño hijo.

Desde hace 35 largos años se dedica a esta actividad. La ropa la adquiere esporádicamente pero a precios muy altos. Por tal razón es que acude a CEPRODEL para recibir apoyo crediticio y así adquirir la mercadería y luego comercializarla.

Es necesario destacar que actualmente tiene un total de 7 créditos pagados en tiempo y forma. Estos han sido destinados para la compra de los productos y mejora de la calidad de vida de ella, su hija y su nieto.

loans.use: Purchase clothes

loans.name: Zarifa

texts.en: Ms. Zarifa is low-income, vulnerable woman (her sone is pictured). She is 56 and lives with her family in the village of Saatli city in the central part of Azerbaijan Republic. Zarifa has a herd of five cows. She started her business with the assistance of her son five years ago with one cow, and now she ihas ncreased the number of animals in the herd up to five. Now she has applied to Normicro Saatli branch to receive a $300 loan to build the open shed for the cattle.

loans.use: To build an open shed for cattle

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Elsa Antonieta

texts.es:
Elsa belongs to the group, Cesar Vallejo, located in Jr Bolognesi 195, in the district of Calleria, in the state of Ucayali. She is 55 years old and has 5 kids who depend on her. She is married and her husband is a farmer. With the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos of $300 she decided in a small store.

Now she has a store installed in her own house, and she gets up at 6am to prepare breakfast for her kids and husband, and then she works in the store until 10pm.

With the loan of $1000, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy a sack of rice, a sack of sugar, a packet of noodles, one carton of milk, one carton of oil, one tin of food, one box of soap and one box of detergent.

Elsa is very happy to work with Manuela Ramos; it is a great help to all the women who want to start a business and she also feels more secure in herself and her family is happy for her.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Elsa pertenece al banco comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en Jr. Bolognesi 195, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años y es madre de 5 hijos menores de edad, es casada y su esposo es agricultor. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en una pequeña bodega. En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega surtida instalada en su propia casa, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos y esposo y luego se dedica a atender la bodega hasta las 10 p.m. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 paquete de fideos, 1 caja de leche, 1 caja de aceite, 1 caja de conservas, 1 caja de jabón y 1 bolsa de detergentes. Elsa se siente muy feliz de trabajar con Manuela Ramos, es una gran ayuda para todas las mujeres que quieren poner un negocio y también se siente mas segura de si misma y su familia está contenta por ella.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, noodles, milk etc / Compra de abarrotes (arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, etc)

loans.name: Jose Guadalupe

texts.es:
I have worked in a factory for years so that I could obtain public housing with ease. Approximately one year ago, I acquired a house, and now I have to make some improvements on it to provide more comfort for my family. Above all, however, I urgently need to install some window safety bars to give my family more security at night. I am requesting this loan in order to install window safety bars on my home.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

“He trabajado durante años en una maquiladora para lograr tener la facilidad de obtener una casa de interés social, hace aproximadamente 1 año que me la entregaron, y ahora necesito hacerle algunas mejoras para que mi familia este más cómoda, pero sobre todo me urge poner las protecciones en las ventanas para darles más seguridad en las noches” Solicito este préstamo para instalar protecciones en las ventanas de mi vivienda.

loans.use: Installation of home window safety bars

loans.name: Maria Rita

texts.es:
Maria belongs to the group, Cesar Vallejo, loacted in the Bolognesi 125 street, in the Calleria district, in the state of Ucayali. She is 52 years old, and has 3 kids, all of whom are adults. She is married and her husband is an independent merchant. With the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos of $300 she decided to invest in fizzy drinks.

Now she sells candy from home, and she also has a car which helps her to gain more income. She gets up at 6am to do house work and also to sells her drinks.

With the loan of $3000, which she will pay back in 5 months, she will buy candy and drinks, and she will invest in the upkeep of her car.

Maria is very happy as her business is growing more and more and her kids are very grateful for the sacrifices that she has made for them. She is also happy that she has had good times and made many friends with Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora María pertenece al banco comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en pasaje Bolognesi 125, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 52 años y es madre de 3 hijos, todos independientes. Es casada y su esposo es un comerciante independiente. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decidió invertir en la venta de gaseosas. En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de gaseosas en su casa, además cuenta con un motocarro que le genera un ingreso adicional. Se levanta a las 6 a.m. para realizar las labores del hogar y simultáneamente atiende a sus clientes en la venta de gaseosas. Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará golosinas, gaseosas y otra parte de capital lo invertirá en el mantenimiento de su motocarro (activo) María se siente muy feliz y contenta porque el negocio crece más y más y sus hijos están muy agradecidos por todo el sacrificio que hizo por ellos y además siente que con Manuela Ramos ha encontrado muchas alegrías y amigas.

loans.use: To buy fizzy drinks and candy / Compra de golosinas y gaseosas. Mantenimiento del activo

loans.name: Freddy Javier

texts.es:
For the last 22 years, Freddy C. has specialised in the sale of quicklime and cement. He sells his products on a site on the outskirts of la Estación market in León. He devotes himself to this business due the necessity of providing for his wife and three sons all things necessary to survive.

Due to the fact that sales have been very low and also that the suppliers of quicklime and cement are currently asking high prices, Señor C. recognises the need to invest in his business and study the means of acquiring other products which are more profitable and will generate a better income.

To acquire quicklime and cement, Freddy has taken out loans with Ceprodel for the last two years, using these to obtain his merchandise. It’s important to stress that all these loans have been repaid on time by Señor C.. He now has a credit record of 8 loans.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

El negocio a que se dedica el señor Freddy C. es a la venta de cemento y cal desde hace 22 años. Vende sus productos en un local en las afueras del mercado la Estación en León. Se involucra a este negocio por la necesidad de brindarles a su esposa y tres hijos el apoyo que tanto necesitan para sobrevivir.

Debido a que sus ventas han estado muy bajas y además, los proveedores de la cal y el cemento presentan precios altos, el señor C. se ve en la necesidad de ir reinvirtiendo en su negocio y estudiando la manera de adquirir otros productos mas rentables y que generen mayores ingresos.

Para la adquisición de la cal y el cemento, Freddy ha realizado préstamos en Ceprodel desde hace dos años habiéndole beneficiado estos para obtener su mercadería. Es necesario destacar que todos y cada uno de estos préstamos han sido pagados en tempo y forma por el señor C.. Su record crediticio es de 8 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase cement and quicklime

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma belongs to the group, Cesar Vallejo, located in the Padre Abad 199 street, in the district of Calleria, in the state of Ucayali. She is 62 years old and has 6 kids, all of whom are adults. She also adopted a boy and she considers him as another son. She is married and her husband is retired. With the first loan of $300 that she received from Manuela Ramos, which she invested in clothes and selling beauty products.

Now she has a small workshop in her house where she makes clothes and sells beauty products. She gets up at 6am to make breakfast for her son and husband, and then she makes clothes.

With the loan of $1,700, which she will pay back over a period of 5 months, she will invest $200 in cotton, $200 in cloth, $200 in needles, elastic, buttons and clasps.

Norma is very happy and works with a lot of enthusiasm as she now has the economic suppor of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Norma pertenece al banco comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en pasaje Padre Abad 199, distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre de 6 hijos, todos independientes, también adoptó a un niño y lo considera como si fuera un hijo más, es casada y su esposo está jubilado. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decidió invertir en la confección de ropa y comercialización de productos de belleza. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño taller de confección de prendas de vestir y venta de productos de belleza instalado en su casa. Se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno de su hijo y esposo y luego se dedica a la confección de sus prendas. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,700, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de S/. 200 en algodón, S/. 200 en telas, S/. 200 en agujas, cierres, blondas botones y elásticos. Norma se siente muy contenta, con más ánimos de trabajar porque ahora cuenta con un respaldo económico gracias al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: To buy material (cotton, cloth, needles) / Compra de materiales (algodón, telas, agujas, etc)

loans.name: Humay

texts.en: Ms. Humay is a low-income, vulnerable woman. She is 36, married, and has two children and lives in the village of Saatli city in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Humay owns a small herd of milk cows. She sells milk in the Saatli bazaar. Her family expenditures are going up as her children grow. Humay plans to increase the number of cattle to make her income higher. But this project requires investment. This winter she applied for $500 from the Normicro Saatli branch. She hopes this credit will help her change her family life.

loans.use: To buy a cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
A few months ago, I was able to obtain public housing. To be frank, however, I feel that the house is very unsafe because the windows can be opened easily. I would like to install window safety bars, thus giving my family comfort and especially safety. I am requesting a loan of $550.00 USD to install window safety bars on my home.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

“Hace poco tiempo que me entregaron mi casa pero la verdad la siento muy insegura ya que las ventanas se pueden abrir con mucha facilidad, me gustaría poner protecciones y así darle a mi familia comodidad y sobre todo seguridad”. Solicito $ 550.00 dlls para instalar protecciones en las ventanas de mi vivienda.

loans.use: Installation of home window safety bars

loans.name: Genara

texts.en:
Genara S. is a single mother who cares for her three-year-old daughter in a rented house.  She provides for herself and her daughter by running a small grocery store near the house.  She began this business with the help of funds given to her by her ex-boyfriend.

With the profits she has made along and with some savings she had, Genara now owns the store as an independent business woman. Genara is an entrepreneur with the future of her daughter in mind.  In order to make her store more successful she needs to purchase a refrigerator to keep her goods, especially the meat products like sausage, in good condition.  Without refrigeration the meat risks going bad in the extreme heat of Paraguay.

With the improvements to her business, she hopes it will one day lead to owning her own house and having the ability to send her daughter to school.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and freezer

loans.name: Restituta

texts.en:
Restituta Jara was born in the city of Capita December 9, 1962.  She has been married for more than 10 years to Emiliano Reyes Acosta and they have a twenty-year-old daughter, Andrea.  Their daughter is currently working at the hospital in the maternity ward as part of her studies to become an obstetrician.  Restituta is happy that her daughter is working towards a profession and is in her graduate studies.  Currently, Restituta owns a small grocery shop and is working towards increasing its size and profits. 

Since 2002, Restituta has worked with the Fundación Paraguaya and they have allowed her to have success in and grow her grocery store business.  Although her business has increased, it still has a long way to go.  With the assistance of a loan, Restituta will improve the infrastructure of her store and buy more merchandise like groceries in bulk, drinks and refreshments, alongside other necessities.

loans.use: To better the infrastructure of his shop and to buy grocery items in bulk: dairy items, drinks and other merchandise.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy G. is a 30-year-old mother of two very young sons.  Her husband works as a chauffeur with her father in a competitive business.  They began this business with the initial investment from her husband’s savings.

They wish to expand the services of the business and refreshments for their clients.  The loan she is asking for will allow her to buy drinks like beer and soda, and other food goods for the customers to purchase. 

This is a young couple working together in their growing business.  They have the entrepreneur spirit and hope to provide more for their two children in the future.

loans.use: To buy wine, beer, sugar and other food goods.

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.en:
Julio Cesar J. was born on May 22, 1957 in the city of Luque.  He has lived there his entire life and has been married since the age of twenty-five to Georgina Quiñonez Avalos. Together they have seven children, three who are still in high school.  Julio is a traveling merchant who, along with two other men, sell chairs, tables, and other pieces of wood furniture.  

Currently, Julio receives financial assistance from his eldest son Agustin, a carpenter, and his wife Rosana, a fashion designer.  He wishes to become independent from his son’s help, since soon his son will have a family of his own to support.  In order to become independent, Julio needs a loan to increase the amount of goods he is selling.  With the money, he will buy more wood, chairs, and large and small tables.

loans.use: To buy wood, chairs, stools, and small and large tables.

loans.name: Sergio Luis Sanchez

texts.en:
Sergio Sanchez was born in the city of Asunción on October 1, 1982. He is a young single guy who lives with his parents. Along with working as an electrician, he also spends time as a traveling salesman with the help of his father. Together they sell electric goods like fluorescent light bulbs, light fixtures, and cables among other articles.

The business that he is building has been financed by Fundación Paraguaya, a micro credit institute since the year 2003. He has been trustworthy with his payments and is now looking to increase the number and diversity of electric products he is selling. As a young spirited man who is knowledgeable both as an electrician and a businessman, his great plan is to one day open his own hardware store.

loans.use: To buy general electronic products.

loans.name: Miguel Laureano

texts.en:
Miguel A. is a mechanic who has been working on cars and automobiles for twenty years. He is married to Fermina Bogarin and together they have two children who are currently attending school. He began gaining skills as a mechanic while he assisted his father as a car shop secretary. His father also worked in a car shop and taught Miguel the skills he needed for his future profession. They repaired and sold used cars in his father’s business.

After working for over fifteen years alongside his father, Miguel parted and began his own business. He has been independent from his father’s business for three years now. His wife Fermina works in the business as well, helping to provide for their children. With a loan he and his wife would purchase more tools, keys, a hydraulic automobile jack, a hydraulic press, and other car parts. Besides increasing the size of his shop and making their business even more successful, Miguel would like his children to someday reach the university level in their studies, something he did not get to do because of a lack of money.

loans.use: To buy tools, keys, a hydraulic automobile jack and hydraulic press, along with other repair tools.

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.es:
The sale of cosmetics and jewelry is a very competitive business due to the fact that there exist many competitors that offer the same products. In the market in León, Señora Lucrecia Q. has been dedicated for ten years to selling cosmetics and jewelry; she has a stand in a very strategic location where it's visited by many people. Things started out difficult for her because she sold her products in the outskirts of the market. On some occasions she didn't even earn a cent in a day and on other days she made just enough for her meals.

With the desire to improve her business, Señora Lucrecia has completed loans through Ceprodel that have benefited her directly by permitting her business to acquire greater quantities of cosmetic products and jewelry and improve her standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La venta de cosméticos y bisuterías es un negocio muy competitivo por el hecho de que existen muchos competidores que ofertan los mismos productos. En el mercado la estación en León, la señora Lucrecia Q. se dedica desde hace 10 años a la comercialización y venta de los cosméticos y bisuterías teniendo su puesto en un local muy estratégico donde es muy visitado por muchas personas. Sus inicios fueron muy difíciles por el motivo de que inicia con una pana donde colocaba sus productos y los vendía en las afueras del mercado en la acera. En algunas ocasiones no ganaba ni un centavo en el día y en otras ocasiones obtenía por lo meno para sus alimentos.

Con el deseo de superar en su negocio, la señora Lucrecia ha realizado créditos en Ceprodel que le han beneficiado de manera directa en su negocio permitiéndole adquirir mayores cantidades de productos cosméticos y bisuterías y además ha logrado elaborar panes ornados para su respectiva venta y mejoramiento de su nivel de vida.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics and jewelry

loans.name: Kuña Kyre´ÿ Group

texts.en:
In the city of Yaguarón, a little more than nine miles from the main city Paraguarí, there is a group of 18 women who have come together to ask for a loan. They have lucrative businesses selling everyday goods like food and house supplies.

Together they have formed a support group and depend on one another to help repay the loans that are given to them. The group has taken on the name Kuña Kyre´ÿ; the name is in the second official language of Paraguay – Guaraní. It means “Active Woman”. All of these women have excellent qualifications and have formed an even greater system where each woman relies on the others to be accountable to repaying her loan. Together they bring different skills, businesses and specializations ranging from hairdressing to specializing in meats and breads.

loans.use: The loan will be invested in buying goods such as fabric, thread, meat, drinks, milk, cooking oil, pasta, rice, flour, baking power, beauty shop supplies, hair accessories, cleaning products and feed for cattle

loans.name: Sandra Isabel

texts.es:
In the outskirts of the market in the station of Leon, we found Ms. Sandra Isabel Z.. She’s a businessperson, who has been selling charcoal, brooms and animal cages for over 20 years. She started her mobile service in the streets of Leon, but she contemplated that her gains didn’t cover her expenses. She decided to get her own space at the market. In little time her prayers were answered and she received immense increases in her sales.

Her only problem is that market doesn’t present the right conditions for her business; there is no roof. She’s afraid some of her products might get wet when the rainy season comes around. She also needs to invest in her products to offer greater quantities and new products to capture more clients.

Ceprodel has offered her unconditional support when she has requested it. Her priority at the moment is to better the location of her business. Her credit record now includes seven successful loans.

Translated from Spanish by Edith of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

En las afueras del mercado la Estación de León, encontramos a la señora Sandra Isabel Z.. Es comerciante que desde hace 20 años se dedica a vender carbón, escobas y jaulas para aves. Su negocio lo comenzó ambulante en las calles de León pero al contemplar que sus ganancias no cubrían sus gastos del hogar decide solicitar un local en el mercado a la Alcaldía de León. Al poco tiempo su petición era contestada y al recibir su tramo comienza a vender sus productos al aire libre

La problemática que atraviesa la señora Z. es que su localidad no presenta las condiciones para el negocio puesto que no posee techo lo que ocasiona que en tiempos de invierno sus productos se mojen. Además necesita invertir en sus productos para ofrecer mayores cantidades y nuevos productos y así captar mas clientes.

Su apoyo incondicional ha sido Ceprodel quien le ha brindado apoyo cuando ella lo solicita. Su prioridad en este momento es mejorar su localidad y para ello hará uso de estos créditos que solo Ceprodel le ofrece. Su record crediticio es de 7 créditos.

loans.use: Buy charcoal and bird cages.

loans.name: Alba Francisca

texts.es:
Alba Francisca O. has been cutting, dying and styling hair in her small beauty salon in the city of León for the past 12 years.

She has had a knack for this branch of work since she was young. For this reason, she developed her skills until becoming a professional in this field. She is married and has a son under her care. She struggles daily in order raise her young son.

Despite having her own business space, she needs to invest in her business, which is why she is searching for a way to obtain a loan from Ceprodel so that she can purchase beauty supplies such as hair dyes, hair cream, towels, gels, etc. To date, she has requested 5 loans, all paid in full and in a timely manner, which have strongly benefited the expansion and development of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Alba Francisca O., desde hace 12 años se dedica al negocio de cortado de cabello, tintes y peinados en un pequeño salón de belleza propio ubicado en la ciudad de León

Desde muy pequeña se destacaba por ser muy inclinada a este ramo de la belleza y por tal motivo fue desarrollando esa habilidad a lo largo de su vida hasta llegar a convertirse en una trabajadora profesional en este ramo. Es madre casada y con un hijo a su cargo que día a día lucha para brindarle sus comodidades ya que es muy pequeño de edad.

A pesar de que tiene su propio local, le es necesario invertir en su negocio por lo que busca la manera de cómo obtener financiamiento en Ceprodel para la compra y adquisición de productos como los tintes, cremas, toallas, gelatinas, etc. Actualmente acumula un total de 5 créditos pagados en tiempo y forma que le han beneficiado fuertemente en el crecimiento y desarrollo de su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty supplies

loans.name: Jamil Del Socorro

texts.es:
Ms. R. is a single mother who is experiencing a difficult situation because she has 5 young children under her care. For this reason, she works diligently selling apparel in the “la Estación” market in León.

Before starting this business, she used to work as a seamstress, but her low wages were insufficient to cover her household expenses. In light of this problem, she firmly decided to sell clothing. She carries out price comparisons in order to choose the best supplier that will offer her the lowest price.

To date, she has requested 11 loans from CEPRODEL, loans which have been of great benefit to her because they have allowed her to not only purchase clothing from her suppliers, but also to partly improve her town's condition.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora R. es una madre soltera que atraviesa una difícil situación por el hecho de que posee 5 pequeños hijos a los que debe mantener y para ello muy esforzadamente se dedica a la venta de ropa en lo interno del mercado la Estación en el Departamento de León.

Antes de iniciar este negocio la señora R. se dedicaba a realizar trabajos de costurera pero sus bajos ingresos eran insuficientes para cubrir los gastos de su hogar. Partiendo de este problema, decide muy firmemente comenzar a adquirir ropa para comercializarla por lo que realiza cotizaciones en varios lugares para seleccionar al proveedor que mas barato le venda la ropa.

Hoy en dia ha realizado un total de 11 créditos en CEPRODEL que le han sido de sumo apoyo ya que ha adquirido la ropa de sus proveedores y además ha mejorado en parte las condiciones de su localidad.

loans.use: Purchase of apparel

loans.name: Ivonne Del Socorro

texts.es:
Señora Ivonne lives in the Montecristi neighborhood of Managua. She is dedicated to the sales of used clothing out of her home. This business provides the income that her family needs to live. Ivonne is married and has two older daughters who still live at home and help with the household jobs and business. Her husband is a senior citizen who is very old and supports the family with the money that he receives monthly from social security. Ivonne has been in this business for four years now, and the majority of her clients are neighbors who have few economic resources and have to purchase second-hand clothing. Presently, Ivonne wants to buy a bundle of clothes for children, women, and men, because she does not have a lot currently in stock for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La Señora Ivonne habita en el barrio Montecristi de Managua, se dedica a la venta de ropa usada en su casa de habitación, este negocio provee el ingreso que la familia necesita para vivir. Doña Ivonne es casada y tiene dos hijas mayores de edad, pero que aún vive en su casa y son quienes le ayudan con los oficios de la casa y el negocio. Su esposo es un señor de muy avanzada edad y aporta a la familia con el dinero que recibe mensualmente del seguro social. Doña Ivonne está en este negocio desde hace 4 años, la mayoría de sus clientes son sus vecinos quienes por contar con bajos recursos económicos tienen que acceder a esta ropa de segunda mano. Actualmente Doña Ivonne quiere comprar una paca de ropa para niños, damas y caballeros, porque no cuenta con mucha existencia del producto en su negocio

loans.use: Purchase a bundle of various clothing.

loans.name: Maria Ligia

texts.es:
Maria Ligia G. is a mother of three children in scholastic age. She is a hard worker that has dedicated her self to sell clothes for the last 30 years in the city of Leon in the Station market. She started her business with a total of U$ 200, that were her savings through her housewife life, that was her occupation before she started to sale clothes.

In spite of the difficult economic situation that she is going trough because of the very low sales, she does not lose the hope that her business will excel and will generate greater income to maintain her three dear children. Ceprodel has support her and give her loans that have fortified her business and have improved the situation of her house. Her present need is to invest in greater amounts of clothes in order to keep providing for her family.

Maria Ligia G. es madre de tres hijos en edad escolar; es muy esforzada ya que se dedica a la venta de ropa que tiene desde hace 30 años en la ciudad de León específicamente en el mercado la Estación. Inició con un total de U$ 200 (Doscientos dólares) producto de sus ahorros realizados a lo largo de su vida cuando realizaba el trabajo de ama de casa que era su dedicación antes de tener la venta de ropa.

A pesar de la difícil situación económica que atraviesa debido a que las ventas están muy bajas, elle no pierde las esperanzas de que su negocio sobresaldrá y le generará mayores ingresos para mantener a sus tres queridos hijos. Por esta razón Ceprodel le ha brindado mucho apoyo con la entrega de créditos que le han fortalecido su negocio y han mejorado la situación de su vivienda. Su necesidad actual invertir en mayores cantidades de ropa para así satisfacer sus necesidades y las de su hogar.

loans.use: To buy Clothes and resale  them

loans.name: Ramón

texts.es:
Mr. Ramon M.’ business is the sale of footwear. This has been his business for 21 years in the city of Leon in Nicaragua. It is a very popular business in this market because he sells all kind of shoes, of different colors and sizes. He sells both women and men shoes.

He is married and has three children, he works hard to provide for them and fulfill all their needs. He opens his business every day from very early in the morning and begins to work with the support of his wife and children. His goal is to extend his premises and offer greater amounts of shoes and the best styles, the best brands and in addition the best prices to get more costumers.

He has borrowed money from Ceprodel that he has used to buy greater amounts of footwear and to cover his family needs. His loan’s record is 10 loans with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva volunteer.

La venta de calzados es el negocio al que se dedica el señor Ramón M. desde hace 21 años en la ciudad de León en Nicaragua. Su negocio es muy común en el sector de calzados de este mercado debido a que oferta zapatos de todo tipo, todo color y todo tamaño para damas y para caballeros.

Es casado y con tres hijos a su responsabilidad por los que lucha fuertemente para mantenerlos y brindarle todas sus necesidades. Todos los días desde muy temprano en la mañana abre su negocio y comienza a trabajar con el apoyo de su esposa y de sus hijos. Su meta es ampliar su local y brindar mayores cantidades de zapatos con los mejores estilos, las mejores marcas y además los mejores precios para así ganar mas clientelas en su local.

Consiente de la necesidad de invertir ha realizado créditos en Ceprodel que los ha utilizado para la adquisición de mayores cantidades de calzados y para las necesidades de su hogar. Su record crediticio es de 10 créditos con Ceprodel.

loans.use: To buy footwear

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
Mrs. Flor de Maria is married, and has 6 children, a boy and 5 girls; 3 of them are already professionals and the other 3 are in high school. Flor de Maria and her husband have worked hard to provide for their family and to be able to give an education to their children.

Flor de Maria’s husband works selling clocks, computers, necklaces door to door in the markets of Managua. Flor de Maria has been dedicating herself to sale “fritanga” which is a meat and vegetables fried meal.

The business has been growing in variety and clients. She is asking for a loan because she wants to invest in her business and be able to offer more products. Her goal is to have a fritanga restaurant that offers more comfort to her clients

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Flor de Maria es casada, y tiene 6 hijos, un varón y 5 mujeres; 3 de ellos ya son profesionales, y los demás están en educación secundaria. Doña Flor de Maria y su esposo han trabajado arduamente para poder sacar adelante a su familia y poderle dar estudios a sus hijos. El esposo de doña Flor de Maria trabaja vendiendo relojes, calculadoras, collares de forma ambulante en los mercados de Managua, y doña Flor de Maria desde hace 14 años se dedica al negocio de la venta de fritanga, el cual con el paso de los años ha ido creciendo en variedad y clientela. Doña Flor necesita el crédito porque quiere invertir más en su negocio, poniendo a la venta mayor catidad y variedad de productos. Por que su deseo dentro de algunos años, es tener una fritanga con más comodidades para sus clientes

loans.use: To buy vegetables and meat for her business

loans.name: Angelica Adelaida

texts.es:
Angelica Perez is 32 years old. She is a single mother and has a 6 years old boy. She lives in the reparto neighborhood of Managua, which has one of the highest delinquency rates of the City. She is an Elementary teacher in the school district.

Her house is built with wood pieces and zinc,. She is asking for a loan to built a concrete house. She wants to buy the construction materials and begin to built a safer house for her and her child. Although she lives in very humble conditions, Angelica is very entrepreneur and her dream is to be able to see a finished house.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva volunteer.

Angélica P. tiene 32 años de edad. Es soltera y tiene un niño de 6 años. Habita en el barrio reparto Shick de Managua, uno de los barrios con más índice delincuencial de la Ciudad. Es maestra de educación primaria en el colegio del barrio. Actualmente su casa está hecha de tablas y zinc, es por eso que solicita el préstamo para empezar a hacer su casa de concreto, quiere comprar materiales de construcción para empezar a levantar su vivienda, y así poder sentirse más segura ella junto a su niño. Aunque habita en condiciones muy humildes, Angélica es muy emprendedora y su sueño es poder ver su casa terminada.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her house

loans.name: Yolanda's Group

texts.en:
Luz, Yolanda and Herminia have belonged to the community bank Desarrollo for 3, 5, and 3 years respectively.

Luz is 38 years old, she is married and has two children. Luz sells food staples such as flour, rice and oil from her mother's house. When she started with the community bank she only sold a few products, but now her store is well stocked.

Yolanda is also married and has five children. She is 38 years old. Yolanda has been selling vegetables from a stand, which she owns, since she was very young. Furthermore, Yolanda and her husband have a motorcycle taxi that brings in additional income. Previously, Yolanda sold food staples from her mother’s house and is now thinking of re-opening this business.

Herminia is 54 years old. She is a widow and has ten children. Herminia sells typical breads such as chapla, which is similar to pita bread. She sells her bread near the bus station in Ayacucho. Sometimes Herminia rents an oven and makes her bread. Other times she buys bread to re-sell later.

Luz, Yolanda and Herminia need loans of 1200, 1000, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying rice, sugar, beans, milk, bear, soft drinks, spinach, parsley, cilantro, flour, butter, and anis.

As part of the community bank they have learned to be responsible, punctual, to have high self-esteem, and to save. Luz, Yolanda, and Herminia will use their savings to put a roof on their house and pay for anything unexpected. Their dreams are to continue developing their business, open a grocery store in their house, buy a car, and give a good education to their children.

loans.use: Luz, Yolanda and Herminia need loans of 1200, 1000, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying rice, sugar, beans, milk, bear, soft drinks, spinach, parsley, cilantro, flour, butter, and anis.

loans.name: Juana Claudia's Group

texts.en:
Miluska, Maximiliana and Juana belong to the community bank Desarrollo. Miluska and Maximiliana have been members for less than one year and Juana has belonged for three. Miluska is currently the president of her bank. In the community bank they have learned to how to treat their children, how to avoid domestic violence, responsibility, and punctuality, how to save, and how to work together.

Miluska is 27 years old and lives with her partner. By profession she is a teacher. Miluska sells beauty products from a catalogue and owns a car that her husband drives as a taxi.

Maximiliana is 40 years old. She is married and has five children. For the past four years Maximiliana has been buying bread from different bakeries and then selling it to stores. Previously, she sold vegetables from a cart, but changed in order to make more profit.

Juana is 57 years old. She is married and has nine children, four of whom still live with her. Juana is a native of the town of Huamanguilla, where she grows corn, and wheat. Along with other grains, which she buys, Juana sells her products from the market in Ayacucho. In addition, during certain seasons Juana sells candies and other sweets from a cart in the central square of Ayacucho.

Miluska, Maximiliana, and Juana need loans of 600, 400, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying, bread, flour, peas, wheat, and barley, as well as repairing their car. Each member of the community bank has an interest earning savings account and Miluska, Maximiliana and Juana plan to use their savings to build homes, or improve their businesses. They have many dreams such as improving their homes, finding a steady job, getting a masters degree, and that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Miluska, Maximiliana and Juana need loans of 600, 400, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying, bread, flour, peas, wheat, and barley, as well as repairing their car.

loans.name: Nancy's Group

texts.en:
Haydee, Obdulia and Nancy have belonged to the community bank “Cusi Urpi”, which means "happy bird" in Quechua, for one year, four months, and three years respectively. In their community bank they have learned to save, to be responsible, how to run their business, family planning techniques, and how to avoid getting sick.

Haydee is 19 years old and is single. She sells ceviche, a traditional dish made from marinating fish in lemon juice, near the college. She has had this business for two years. Haydee would like to improve her business by adding more tables. In addition, she would like to buy a cement mixer, which she could then rent out. At the same time she is studying to be able to enter the University.

Obdulia is a single mother. She is 43 years old and has two children. Obdulia sells food staples such as flour and sugar from a stand in the April Market of Ayacuhco. Furthermore, Obdulia has a small piece of land outside of town where she grows alfalfa to also sell in the market.

Nancy is 28 years old and single. She sells cosmetics from a catalogue to her family and friends. Nancy is thinking of opening a salon.

Haydee, Obdulia and Nancy need loans of 400, 200, and 600 soles (3 soles =$1), which will be invested in buying alfalfa seeds, sugar, rice, paying their laborer, tables, fish, and to open a salon. The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving, and each associate has an interest earning savings account. They are saving to buy a cement mixer, to pay for medical care for their daughter, and to open a beauty salon. Their dreams are to own a solid home, be professionals, that their children will be professionals, and to open their own salon.

loans.use: Haydee, Obdulia and Nancy need loans of 400, 200, and 600 soles (3 soles =$1), which will be invested in buying alfalfa seeds, sugar, rice, paying their laborer, tables, fish, and to open a salon.

loans.name: Asalia

texts.es:
Asalia belongs to the group, Women with a Future, located in Jr. Ruperto Perez 227, in the district of Yarina Cocha, in the state of Ucayali. She is 47 years old and has 4 kids who all depend on her. She is separated. With the first loan of $3000 that she received from Manuela Ramos she invested in used clothes.

She now sells a variety of merchandise such as clothes, shoes, earrings, sandals etc. She normally gets up at 6am to open her store, and she works with clients all day long.

With a loan of $1,100, which she will pay back in 5 months, she will buy new and second hand clothes, such as t-shirts, polo shirts, trousers, dresses, tops, shorts, underwear etc, in all sizes and styles.

Asalia feels good about the business that she has managed to consolidate, and thanks to this she can support her kids' studies. She is very grateful for the support that Manuela Ramos shows her.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Asalia pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres con Futuro, ubicado en Jr. Ruperto Pérez 227, distrito de Yarina Cocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años y es madre de 4 hijos que aún dependen de ella y es separada. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la compra y venta de ropas usadas. En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de una variada gama de mercaderías como ropas, zapatos, aretes, correas, sandalias, etc. Usualmente se levanta a las 6 a.m. para abrir su establecimiento y durante todo el día se dedica a la atención al público. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,100, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de ropas de primera y segunda, tales como camisas, polos, pantalones, vestidos, blusas, short, ropa interior, etc., en todas las tallas y modelos. Asalia se siente bien por el negocio que ha podido consolidar, gracias a ello puede apoyar en los estudios a sus hijos, también se siente muy agradecida al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: To buy clothes / Compra de ropa

loans.name: Betty Gloria

texts.es:
Betty belongs to the group, Women with a Future, based in Jr. 2 de Mayo, in the district of Calleria, in the state of Ucayali. She is 59 years old and has 7 kids; 5 of whom are adults, the other two depend on her. She is married and her husband is a bricklayer. With the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos she decided to invest in a small sewing workshop.

Now, she uses this workshop to make all sorts of clothes. She usually gets up very early to look after her kids, and then she dedicates herself to making clothes to give to her clients.

With the loan of $1,200, which she will pay back in 5 months, she will buy different types of cloth, different coloured threads, all types of lace, patterns, and she will fix her sewing machine.

Betty has shown that Manuela Ramos has helped her a lot, and this is how she carries on and always pays her loan back on time. She is really happy with what she has acheived.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Betty pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres con Futuro, ubicado en Jr. 2 de Mayo 180, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 59 años, es madre de 7 hijos, 5 mayores de edad y 2 que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo es maestro albañil. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en un pequeño taller de costura. En la actualidad ella cuenta con un taller de costura para diversos tipos de prendas de vestir, usualmente se levanta muy temprano para atender a sus hijos y luego se dedica a la confección de las prendas para entregar a sus clientes. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,200, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará telas de diversas calidades, hilos de diferentes colores, blondas de todo tipo, adornos y también invertirá en el mantenimiento a su maquina remalladora. Betty manifiesta que Manuela Ramos es una gran ayuda para nosotras y por eso sigue adelante y pagando muy puntual sus préstamos. Está muy contenta con todo lo que ha realizado.

loans.use: To buy material (cloth, thread, patterns etc) / Compra de materiales (telas, hilos, adornos, etc)

loans.name: Demetria's Group

texts.en:
Gualberta, Clementina and Demetria have belonged to the community bank “Sumaqcha”, which means "very beautiful" in Quechua, for 13, 4, and 13 years respectively. In the bank they have learned to be responsible, punctual, and how to run their business. In addition they have learned how to take care of their children and how to avoid getting sick.

Gualberta is 42; she is married and has four children. Gualberta has a small store in her house where she sells food staples such as flour and sugar. She started this business two months ago. Before that she sold firewood from her doorstep. Thanks to her savings and a loan from her bank she was able to start her new business.

Clementina is married and has six children, three of whom still live with her. She is 55 years old. Clementina travels to the countrysiD. to sell ice cream, fruit, and other food staples. She buys animals and grains from the country, which she sells in the city of Ayacucho. She also sells prepared food from her home.

Demetria is 56 years old. She is married and has seven children. Demetria sells onions from a cart in the Nery Garcia market of Ayacucho. Previously, she grew the onions in a field she owns but had to stop due to poor health.

Gualberta, Clementina and Demetria need loans of 1000, 600, and 300 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying rice, oil, corn, wheat, candies, beans, soap, chicken, grains, onion, and guinea pigs, which are considered a delicacy in Peru. The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving and each associate has an interest earning account. Clementina plans to use her savings to pay for medical treatment, while Gualberta and Demetria hope to build a house. Their dreams are to own a home, open a café, that their children will be professionals, that their businesses will continue to grow, and that they will have good health.

loans.use: Gualberta, Clementina and Demetria need loans of 1000, 600, and 300 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying rice, oil, corn, wheat, candies, beans, soap, chicken, grains, onion, and guinea pigs, which are considered a delicacy in Peru.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.es:
Dolores belongs to the communal bank of Women with a Future, located in the district of Calleria, in the neighborhood of Ucayali. She is 61 years old, and she is the mother of 11 children and all of her children help take care of her. She is married and her husband is a fisherman. With her first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos she decided to invest in fishing.

At the moment she relies on selling fish to earn her income. She has a motorcar that her son drives. She wakes up at 6 a.m. every morning to make breakfast and then she leaves to sell fish.

With the loan of 1,900 Peruvian Soles, which she will pay in 5 months, she will invest it in tools needed for her duty and paying the person who works with her.

Dolores is very happy, while fishing and the motorcar is really helping her to succeed in her business. She also feels more independent and she counts less on the support of her children and her husband. She hopes for great health in order for her to succeed. She is grateful for the support everyone has provided, especially Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Edith of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Dolores pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres con Futuro, ubicado en Jr. Apurimac 409, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 61 años, es madre de 11 hijos, todos mayores de edad que siempre la apoyan, es casada y su esposo es pescador. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la pesca.

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de venta de pescados al por mayor y con un motokar que es manejado por su hijo. Ella se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno y luego va al puerto y dirige la venta de sus pescados.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,900, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de una red paichitera, mantenimiento del bote y el motor y comprará 30 barras de hielo, 40 galones de combustibles y cubrirá el pago de su personal que trabaja con ella, además hizo el mantenimiento a su motokar, el cual le genera un ingreso diario.

Dolores está muy contenta, tanto el negocio de la pesca como el motokar están dando buenos resultados. También se siente más independiente y cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos y el su esposo. Espera gozar de buena salud para poder seguir adelante. Se siente muy agradecida por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos .

loans.use: Maintenance on her boat and motor, and purchase of fishing supplies.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
Mrs. Elsa belongs to the Nuevo Eden communal bank located in the district of Yarina Cocha in the neighborhood of Ucayal. She is 55 years old. She is mother of 9 children, 6 are adults and 3 still live with her. She is married and her husband is a chainsaw mechanic. With the first loan of 300 Peruvian Soles that she received she decided to invest in the sale of typical food of the region.

Presently she works for herself and operates a small restaurant out of her house. She has to wake up really early to go to the market and buy ingredients for the food that she prepares to sell in the afternoons.

With the loan of 1,500 Peruvian Soles, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will invest in some essential ingredients that she needs to make her business grow. She will purchase 1 large bag of rice, a large slab of meat, 10 kilograms of salted meat, 10 kilograms of sausage, fish, 1 large bag of charcoal, 3 boxes of eggs, 1 large bag of sugar and other necessary items.

Elsa is very happy. During the time that she has been working with Manuela Ramos she has done very well and she is very grateful to the organization for all of the support she has received.

Translated from Spanish by Gabe of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Elsa pertenece al banco comunal Nuevo Edén, ubicado en Jr. 7 de Junio 415, distrito de Yarina Cocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años, es madre de 9 hijos, 6 son mayores de edad y 3 tres aún viven con ella, es casada y su esposo es mecánico de motosierras. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la venta de comidas típicas de la región.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de comidas en su casa, para lo cual se levanta muy temprano para ir al mercado y comprar los insumos para la preparación de los platos y en la tarde sale a vender.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 1 saco de arroz, carne de monte, 10 kilos de cecinas, 10 kilos de chorizo, pescados, 1 saco de carbón, 3 cajas de huevos, 1 saco de azúcar, etc.

Elsa se siente bien. Durante todo el tiempo que viene trabajando con Manuela Ramos le va muy bien y está muy agradecida de la Institución por el apoyo que recibe.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients (sugar, rice, meat, and other necessary items)

loans.name: Floria

texts.es:
Mrs. Floria belongs to Banco Comunal Nuevo Edén, located at Jr. Ruperto Pérez 445, in the district of Yarina Cocha, and in the neighborhood of Ucayali. She is 58 years of age and is mother of 9 children. Her kids are all grown and she is single. With the first loan of 300 Peruvian Soles she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to sell in the market of Yarina Cocha.

Presently she makes her living off of a food stand that she has in the market place of Yarina Cocha. She works at her stand every morning without fail. She wakes up daily at 5 a.m. and takes her products to the market. In the afternoons she relaxes for two hours and then she prepares her food to sell at the market the following day.

With the loan of 1,300 Peruvian Soles, which she will pay off in 5 months, she will invest the money in different ingredients to prepare her food. For example, she will purchase large quantities of rice, sugar, chicken, diverse of condiments, and leaves to make tamales. In addition, she will make some improvements to her stand and she will buy paint and cement, etc.

Floria is very happy and she shows that that’s to her own hard work, her desire to get ahead, and the support she has received from Manuel Ramos she can live a peaceful life.

Translated from Spanish by Johnny of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Floria pertenece al Banco Comunal Nuevo Edén, ubicado en Jr. Ruperto Pérez 445, distrito de Yarina Cocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 58 años, es madre de 9 hijos mayores de edad y es soltera. Con el primer préstamo de S/.300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide vender en el mercado de Yarina Cocha.

En la actualidad cuenta con un puesto de comida en el mercado de Yarina Cocha, en el cual atiende esmeradamente por las mañanas. A diario se levanta a las 5 a.m. para llevar al mercado sus productos y acomodar su mesa para la venta. En las tardes descansa 2 horas y luego se dedica a la preparación de sus comidas para la venta del día siguiente.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de diversos productos para la preparación de sus comidas, como 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, pollos, diversos condimentos, hojas para hacer juanes, además hará algunos arreglos en su puesto para lo cual comprará pintura, cemento, etc.

Floria se siente muy bien y manifiesta que gracias a su esfuerzo, a sus ganas de salir adelante y al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos puede vivir tranquila.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients (rice, sugar, chickens, condiments, etc)

loans.name: Floripe

texts.es:
Mrs. Floripe belongs to the communal bank Nuevo Edén, located at 7 Jr. Dos de Mayo MZ A Lt, in the district of Yarina Cocha, in the neighborhood of Ucayali. She is 38 years old and the mother of 4 children. All of her children are minors. Her husband works as a mechanic. Her last loan was for 300 Peruvian Soles from Manuela Ramos. She has decided to invest in a sort of table that she could display and sell her products from. The products that she sells are candies and snack food.

Right now she works full-time selling candy and snack food. Everyday she wakes up at 6:00 am to make breakfast for all 4 of her children and for her husband. And after that she goes to the market to purchase the supplies that she needs. In the afternoon she starts selling her merchandise on her sidewalk outside of her house.

With the loan of 1,500 Peruvian Soles, which will be repaid back in 5 months, she will buy 1 package of cigarettes 1 package of candies, 1 package of gum, 1 package of cookies, 1 package of chocolate, and some other items that she can sell.

Floripe is very happy because she is economically independent now and she doesn’t have be asking her husband for money because she has enough money to buy what she needs and she can help support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Gabe of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Floripe pertenece al banco comunal Nuevo Edén, ubicado en el Jr. Dos de Mayo Mz A Lt 7, distrito de Yarina Cocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 años, es madre de 4 hijos, todos menores de edad, es casada y su esposo es mecánico. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en un pequeño tablero para la venta de diversas golosinas.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de diversas golosinas. A diario se levanta a las 6 a.m. para hacer el desayuno de sus hijos y el de su esposo, luego va al mercado a comprar sus productos que le faltan y en las tardes sale a vender sus golosinas en la vereda de su casa.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de 1 paquete de cigarros, 1 paquete de caramelos, 1 paquete de chicles, 1 paquete de galletas, 1 paquetes de chocolates, etc.

Floripe se siente muy bien porque es independiente económicamente ya que no tiene que estar pidiendo a su esposo para comprar algunas cosas que ella necesita y puede apoyar a su familia.

loans.use: Purchases desserts and cookies.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Mrs. Gloria belongs to The New Eden Communal Bank, located in the district of Yarina Cocha in the neighborhood of Ucayali. She is 52 years old and the mother of four children. Three of her children are adults and one still depends on her. She is a single mother. With her first loan of 300 Peruvian Soles from Manuela Ramos she decided to invest in a small store and sell “Juanes” (pumpkin fritters) there.

Presently she has a little store in her home and she sells basic items including pumpkin fritters. She starts her day at 6 a.m. She goes to the market and buys the products she needs to stock her store. Every afternoon and evening she spends time making her pumpkin fritters. Then she rests so she can be ready for the next day.

With the loan of 2,200 Peruvian Soles, which she plans to pay back in 5 months, she will invest in products she needs to keep her business going, like 1 sack of rice, 1 box of oil, ½ sack of Flour, 1 sack of sugar, 1 package of noodles, 1 box of milk, 1 bag of detergent, etc.

Gloria is really happy because ever since she is working with Manuela Ramos her sales have gone up, her income is also going up. Her family is doing so well and that makes her extremely happy!

Translated from Spanish by Mariela of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Gloria pertenece al banco comunal Nuevo Edén, ubicado en Jr. 2 de Mayo Mz. G Lt. 7, distrito de Yarina Cocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 52 años, es madre de 4 hijos, 3 mayores de edad y uno que aún depende de ella y es separada. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en una pequeña bodega y venta de picarones.

En la actualidad cuenta con una bodega y también se dedica a la venta de picarones en su casa. Se levanta a las 6.00 a.m. para ir al mercado y comprar los productos que le faltan para la venta en la bodega, en las tardes se dedica a la preparación y venta de picarones y luego descansa para el día siguiente.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,200, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará, 1 saco de arroz, 1 caja de aceite, ½ saco de harina , 1 saco de azúcar, 1 paquete de fideo, 1 caja de leche, 1 bolsa de detergente, etc.

Gloria se siente muy bien porque desde que empezó a trabajar con Manuela Ramos sus ventas aumentaron, sus ingresos económicos también, su familia está bien y eso la hace muy feliz.

loans.use: Purchase grocery goods (rice, oil, flour, etc.)

loans.name: Maximina's Group

texts.en:
Maria, Maximina and Teodora are from the community of San Rafael. They have been part of the community bank “Allim Llamqaqkuna”, which means "work well" in Quechua, for one year.

Maria is 34 years old. She is a single mother and has three children. Maria buys animals and cheeses which she sells door to door and to small stores. Furthermore, she embroiders blankets, bed covers, and cloaks.

Maximina is 40 years old and is married with nine children, seven of whom still live with her. Together with her husband Maximina buys eucalyptus wood that they later sell as fire wood. She also sells fish and chicken parts in her town.

Teodora is married and has two children. She is 33 years old. Teodora buys eucalyptus wood to sell as firewood. Together with her husband Teodora makes beautiful embroidered blankets that she sells in the Santa Clara market. Furthermore, Teodora has several beehives which she uses to make honey.

Maria, Maximina and Teodora need loans of 600, 900, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying corn, cheese, pork, beef, barley, and eucalyptus trees. They plan to use their savings to buy cattle, to pay for their children’s education, and to buy furniture for their house. Maria, Maximina, and Teodora dream of improving their house, having enough capital for their business, and that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Maria, Maximina and Teodora need loans of 600, 900, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying corn, cheese, pork, beef, barley, and eucalyptus trees.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.es:
Mrs. Daisy M. is from the city of Bluefields. She is 45 years old and married to Mr. Joseph Hebbert, they both have 5 children who attend middle school, she pays for these studies with the income from her coconut bread sales. Mrs. M. has more than 10 years of experience, and her potential clients are the inhabitants from Puerto Maritimo. They prefer her because of the quality of her products. Currently, Mrs. M. needs to purchase 300 kilos of flour which has a value of $96 dollars; 200 kilos of sugar, a value of $54; 24 pounds of shortening a value of $24; 3 pounds of baking powder, a value of $6, 100 coconuts, a value of $30, 10 pounds of fruit, a value of $30 and 10 bags of coal, a value of $60. She requests a loan in order to make these purchases and therefore satisfy the markets demand.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Escalante, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. Daisy M. es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 45 años de edad esta casada con el Sr. Joseph Hebberth ambos tienen 5 hijos que cursan estudios secundarios, estos estudios son pagados con el ingreso de la venta de pan de coco. La Sra. M. tiene 10 años de experiencia, sus clientes potenciales son habitantes del Puerto marítimo EL Bluff que la prefieren por la calidad de su producto. En estos momentos la Sra. M. necesita comprar 3 quintales de harina a $32.00 dólares el quintal, 2 quintales de azúcar a $ 27.00 dólares el quintal, 24 libras de manteca a $ 1.00 dólar la libra, 3 libras de levadura a $ 2.00 dólares la libra, 100 unidades de coco a $ 0.30 centavos dólar la unidad, 10 libras de frutas a $ 3.00 dólares la libra y 10 sacos de carbón a $ 6.00 dólares cada saco para poder satisfacer su demanda.

loans.use: Comprar 3 quintales de harina, 2 quintales de azúcar, 24 libras de manteca, 10 sacos de carbón, 3 libras de levadura, 100 unidades de coco, 10 libras de fruta.

payments.comment: La Sra. Morales pago el dia 22 de Febrero  del 2008 no se notifico a tiempo por problemas en la energia electrica.
Equivale a las cuotas numero 5 y 6. Ya cancelo.

loans.name: Jacinta Ofelia

texts.es:
Mrs. Jacinta is a member of the communal bank Women with a Future, located in Wiracocha in the district of Calleriad in the region of Ucayali. She is 55 years old and a mother of three children: one is already independent and two still rely on her. She is married and her husband is a mechanic. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received through Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in the sales of soda.

Presently she is dedicated to renting rooms in her home and selling sodas. She wakes up at 6:00 a.m., prepares breakfast for her kids and husband, and she sets to the administrational duties of renting rooms.

With the loan of 1000 soles, which she will pay back in five months, she will buy 30 corrugated sheets of metal, nails, wood, and five boxes of soda.

Jacinta says that Manuela Ramos is a great help for solving economic problems, and so she feels really happy for all the support offered.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La señora Jacinta pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres con Futuro, ubicado en Jr. Wiracocha 206 – AA.HH Jorge Chávez, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años, es madre de 3 hijos, uno ya es independiente y dos aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo es mecánico. Con el primer préstamo de S/ 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la venta de gaseosas.

En la actualidad se dedica al alquiler de habitaciones en su vivienda y a la venta de gaseosas. Se levanta 6 a.m. prepara el desayuno de sus hijos y de su esposo y se dedica a administrar el alquiler de sus cuartos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 30 planchas de calaminas, clavos, listones, maderas y 5 cajas de gaseosas.

Jacinta dice que Manuela Ramos es una gran ayuda para solucionar sus problemas económicos, por lo cual se siente muy contenta por todo el apoyo brindado.

loans.use: Buy construction materials for rental rooms

loans.name: Lourdes' Group

texts.en:
Agueda, Lourdes and Nazaria are from the community of San Rafael. They have been part of the community bank “Allim Llamqaqkuna”, which means "work well" in Quechua, for six months. In their community bank they have learned how to invest money, take care of and educate their children, and how to save. They mentioned that they all get along and always celebrate each other’s birthdays.

Agueda is 45 years old and has seven children. She sells clothing in the markets around Ayacucho. From the markets she buys meat and cheese, which she sells in the city. She was able to start this business with a loan from her community bank.

Lourdes is 34 years old. She is married and has three children. Lourdes travels to different markets where she buys grains, cheese, animals, and other products that she sells in the city of Ayacucho.

Nazaria is 47 years old. She is married and has seven children. Nazaria buys eucalyptus wood that she chops and later sells as firewood. She was able to start this business with a loan from her community bank.

Agueda, Lourdes and Nazaria need loans of 900, 600, and 900 soles respectively (3 soles = $1) which they will invest in buying pants, sweaters, shits, skirts, blouses, cheeses, meat, wheat, barley, corn, chicken, eucalyptus, and to pay a laborer.

The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving and each associate has an interest earning account. Agueda, Lourdes and Nazaria plan to use their savings to buy a motorcycle taxi, buying a chain saw, and to open their own store. Their dreams are that their children will be professionals, to own land, to build a house in the city of Ayacucho, and to continue to develop their business.

loans.use: Agueda, Lourdes and Nazaria need loans of 900, 600, and 900 soles respectively (3 soles = $1) which they will invest in buying pants, sweaters, shits, skirts, blouses, cheeses, meat, wheat, barley, corn, chicken, eucalyptus, and to pay a laborer.

loans.name: Keyla

texts.es:
Señora Keila is a member of the communal bank called 'New Eden' located in the district of Yarina Cocha in Ucayali. She's 28 years old and a mother of 2 young children. She's married and her husband sells all types of wood. With the first loan she obtained from Manuela Ramos, she decided to open up her own business by buying and selling wood planks.

She currently sells different types of forest wood planks.
