Gorette is 40 years old and married with five children. The husband is a businessman. She sells spare parts. Betty and Suzan have a poultry businesses and want to use the loan to obtain more chicks. Edrine and Winifred have a retail shop businesses. Margret is a tailor and wants to use the loan to buy more cloth and materials. Betty wants to use the loan to purchase more timber for sale.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Oyinade

texts.en: Oyinade W. is 40 years old, married with four children and lives in the town of Shibiri in Lagos state, Nigeria. Since 1997, she has helped support her family by selling food and drinks from a stall in a local market.  Oyinade has been a LAPO member for three years, and has requested a new loan of $450 to by more drinks to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell to her customers

loans.name: Kinaawa D(I) Group

texts.en:
Rose is 45 years old and a single mother of three children. She has a grocery store. She earns about shs 70,000 in profits weekly. She wants to use the extra business profits to construct a house. Evelyn and Racheal have beauty salons. Aida sells used clothes while Annet has a market stall.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items

loans.name: Elo

texts.en: Elo U. is 47 years old, married with five children and hails from the town of ilaje in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has made a living selling frozen fish for the last 15 years,  and has applied for a $700 loan to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more frozen fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice A. O. is 35 years old, married with two children and hails from Ajamgdadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. Ever since completing her training more than two years ago, she has made a living working as a stylist and cosmetologist. She also sells beauty supplies. Alice has been a LAPO client for the last three years, and has applied for a loan of $450 to buy new supplies for her beauty parlor.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for a beauty parlor

loans.name: Kinaawa D(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Florence is 29 years old and married with three children. She has a bakery business. With the extra busines profits she earns, she wants to buy iron sheets for her residential house, which is currently under construction. Annet, Sarah, Viola and Joyce have beauty salon businesses. They want to use the loan to expand their salons.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kinaawa D(Iii) Group

texts.en:
Caroline is 26 years old. She has a retail shop. She sees a business opportunity; she would like to expand her shop to sell wholesale as well. She usually earns shs 60,000 (~$36 USD) in profits weekly. With the extra profits she earns, Caroline intends to start a poultry business. Dorothy has a hardware business. Margret wants to use the loan to purchase more clothes for sale. Joyce sells charcoal. Annet works in a hotel.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To raise capital to improve their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona is an Internally Displaced Person from the Fizuli region located in the southeast part of Azerbaijan. She and her family (her husband is pictured) were relocated to the Lokbatan settlement of Baku city as a result of Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. She and her husband, Bakhtiyar Najafov, trade vegetables and fruits. They have been in this business for more than 8 years. She wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in her business and increase her income. She has had two previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. Now they apply again for $1000, to invest in business.

loans.use: To invest in business

loans.name: Kinaawa C(I) Group

texts.en:
Ruth is 38 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a driver. She has a poultry business. She wants to use the extra profits she earns to invest in the piggery and cultivation businesses. Sophia and Rehema sell used clothes and want to use the loan to increase their stock. Noeline sells firewood.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feed and to raise capital for the other businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Queen

loans.use: To buy more food to sell to her customers

loans.name: Magsud

texts.en: Magsud is an Internally Displaced Person from the Lachin region located in the southeast part of Azerbaijan. He and his family were relocated to Lokbatan settlement in the suburbs of Baku as a result of Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. He trades fruits and vegetables near the marketplace. He wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in the business and increase his income. He borrowed three previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. Now he applies again for $1400 to invest in business. $1200 of this amount will be funded by Kiva and the rest will be funded by Normicro.

loans.use: To invest in business

loans.name: Kinaawa C(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Prossy is a single mother of two children (they are twins). She sells used clothes for a living. She earns about shs 30,000 ($18 USD) in profits each week. Prossy wants to use the extra profits she earns to start a piggery business. Christine wants to use the loan to purchase more goods for her retail shop. Roy has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy hair weaves and braids.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To add to their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kinaawa C(Iii) Group

texts.en: Josephine has a charcoal business. She sells charcoal on retai business. She wants to use the extra profits to complete her residential house that is under construction.Betty and Regina sell snacks and want to use the loan to expand the business. Cissy has a bakery business and intends to use the loan to buy more conatiners. Teo sells used clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Hajibaba

texts.en: Hajibaba is an Internally Displaced Person from the Fizuli region located in the southeast part of Azerbaijan. He and his family were relocated to Lokbatan settlement in the Baku suburbs as a result of Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. He has been tradeing fruits and vegetables in the local market for more than 8 years. He wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in his business and increase his income. He has had two previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. Now he applies again for $1200, to invest in his business.

loans.name: Kinaawa C(Iii) Group

Josephine has a charcoal business. She sells charcoal to retail customers. She wants to use the extra profits she earns to complete her residential house, which is under construction. Betty and Regina sell snacks and want to use the loan to expand their businesses. Cissy has a bakery business and intends to use the loan to buy more conatiners for her business. Teo sells used clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

She is a stylist who sells beauty supplies, and also runs a grinding machine used to process farm items such as pepper and beans. Aina has been a LAPO client for the last three years, and has applied for a new loan of $450 to buy supplies for her salon.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for a beauty parlor

loans.name: Maleyka

texts.en: Maleyka was a resident of Baku, but now she lives in Lokbatan settlement in the Baku suburbs. She has been trading fruits and vegetables in the local market for more than 8 years. She wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in this business and increase her income. She has had two previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. Now she applies again for $1200 to invest in business.

loans.use: To invest in the business

loans.name: Uche

texts.en: Uche P. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the town of Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. Since 1999, she has made a living selling food to the people of her community. She has been a LAPO member for three years, and has applied for a $200 loan to buy more items to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell to her customers

loans.name: Alizamin

texts.en: Alizamin is from the Barda region of Azerbaijan, but now he lives in Lokbatan settlement in the suburbs of Baku. He rents a shop and sells clothing near the marketplace. He has been in this business for more than 5 years. He has taken one previous loan from Normicro Baku branch and successfully paid it back. He wants to increase the number and variety of the goods and he has little of his own funds. He applies again for a loan in amount of $1200. He will repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To increase volume and variety

loans.name: Kinaawa C(Iv) Group

texts.en:
Marget is 35 years old and a single mother of one. She sells African crafts. She wants to use the extra profits she earns to start a small restaurant.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To add to her business and open a restaurant

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty A. is 51 years old, married, has eight children and hails from the town of Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a cosmetologist who also sells supplies from her beauty parlor, and needs a loan of $450 to buy more equipment and products for her business.  She has been in business since 1988, and has been a LAPO client for the past three years.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for a beauty parlor.

loans.name: Allahverdi

texts.en: Allahverdi is a 58-year-old Internally Displaced Person from the Khojavand region situated in the east part of the country, in the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict zone. He lives in the Lokbatan settlement in the suburbs of Baku with his family--his wife and three children. He breeds cattle in the shed that he built. He has been engaged in this business for three years. He buys cattle, raises them and sells them alive to the local market or to butchers. Cattle breeding has become traditional and it can bring good income. Allahverdi wants to develop this business, to increase the number of cows. He wants to buy more calves to add to his livestock.

loans.use: To increase the number of cattle

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 28 years old. He is married and has two children studying in school. After his father died in a terrorist attack, his sister came to live with him in his rented house.

He has a home supplies shop. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new home supplies and new goods. He also wants to paint the shop and renovate it. He wants to develop his business and expand his project to increase his income and save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new home supplies

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is an Internally Displaced Person from the Fizuli region located in the southwest part of Azerbaijan. He and his family were relocated to Lokbatan settlement in the Baku suburbs as a result of the Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. He rents a shop and sells mobile phones. As mobile phones are very popular now, the business is going well. But the number and variety of mobile phones is low, so he wants to increase the volume of his business. As he has little of his own funds, he applies to Normicro Baku branch for a loan in amount of $1000 to invest in his business. He will repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To buy new varieties of phones

loans.name: Shell Ii 2085(A) Group

texts.en:
Norah is 25 years old and married with two children. She has a retail shop. Norah wants to use the extra business profits she earns to pay school fees for her children. She also wants to also start another business. Jane and Christine sell fresh foods. Gertrude sells second-hand clothes and wants to increase her inventory.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To re-invest in the businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Faith

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions

loans.name: Fumilola

texts.en: “I thank LAPO for coming to my aid financially,” says Mrs Fumilola I., who hails from Atinga town in Lagos State, Nigeria. Since 1992, she has supported herself by selling garri in bags. She needs a loan of $450 to buy more garri to sell to her customers. Fumilola is 48 years old, married with four children and has been a LAPO client for the past three years.

loans.use: To buy more bags of garri, a popular Nigerian food made from cassava

loans.name: Shell Ii 2085(B) Group

texts.en:
Barbra is married with two children. She also cares for four dependants. She wants to use the the profits she earns from the business to buy a mortocycle for commercial purposes. Sarah sells fresh foods. Betty has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy a hair dryer. Rebecca runs a retail shop and wants to increase her inventory with the loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cement and iron sheets and raise capital for the other businesses

loans.name: Shell Ii 2085(B) Group

texts.en:
Barbra is married with two children. She also cares for four dependants. She wants to use the profits she earns from her business to buy a mortocycle for commercial purposes. Sarah sells fresh foods. Betty has a beauty salon and wants to use the loan to buy a hair dryer. Rebecca has a retail shop business. With the loan, she would like to increase her inventory.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.name: Tahir

texts.en: Tahir is from the Beylagan region of Azerbaijan, but now he lives in Lokbatan settlement in the suburbs of Baku. He trades cereals such as grain, barley, buckwheat, etc. He buys goods from different regions, transports them to Baku, and sells to wholesalers in the local market. He has been in this business for more than 8 years. He has had two previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. He repaid all loans on time. Now he applies again for $1200 to invest in his business.

loans.use: To invest in business

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.en:
Ms. Gulnaz is a low-income, vulnerable woman (her son is pictured). She is 45, married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.
Gulnaz owns a small herd of cattle. On Saturdays she and her son (pictured) are selling animals she bred, buying calves and then they start to breed them again. The business is going well but needs some improvement. Gulnaz plans to increase the number of calves she purchases to make her income higher. Her family expenditures are going up as her children grow. Gulnaz has the application to receive a $600 loan approved by Normicro Saatli branch. She hopes this credit will help her change her family's life.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Fahriya

texts.en: Fahriya is a refugee from the Shusha region, which is situated in the west part of Azerbaijan, in the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict zone. She lives in the Binagadi settlement in the suburbs of Baku now. She sells clothing in the local market. She has been in this business for more than 3 years. She has taken loans from Normicro Baku branch before and successfully paid back her loans. She wants to increase the number and variety of her goods and she has little of her own funds. She applies again for a loan in the amount of $1075. She will repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Shell Ii 2085(C) Group

texts.en:
Margret is a 40 year old widow with three children and three dependants. She has a salon business. With the profits she earns from the business, Margret intends to buy a piece of land. Eva is a poultry farmer and wants to use the loan to purchase more poultry feed. Aminah has a restaurant business. Jackie's business offers secretarial services like typing, printing and photocopying.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more equipment, including dryers and salon chemicals and provide capital for the other businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Shell Ii 2085(D) Group

texts.en:
Prossy is 38 years old and divorced with four children. She also cares for one dependant. She has a business selling used clothes. Prossy intends to use the profits she earns to secure space in one of the arcades in town to use as a shop. Mary sells fresh foods in the market. Betty offers tailoring services. Safina is a poultry farmer. Winnie sells charcoal.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Zarifa

texts.en: Ms. Zarifa is a low-income, vulnerable woman. She is 56, is married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region. Zarifa owns a herd of milk cows. Every day she sells milk to the local milk processing shop. Her children help her to breed cows. The income from four cows is too low to support the family, and not enough to buy more of cows. That’s why Zarifa applied to Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch for a $600 loan, to buy one more purebred cow to make her monthly income higher. The price of a milk calf is $400; the cost of breeding is $100. The other $100 she plans to save for unexpected expenditures.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Limpia's Group

texts.es:
The contact for the creation of this group was a woman who was a member of another group in the same region. She was told about the program by Sra. Agustina S., and later she organized her neighbors to form this group.

Limpia A., Mónica A., Agustina S. and Mirtha G. sell clothing and lingerie. They will invest their money in the purhcase of merchandise such as t-shirts, pants, bermuda shorts, skirts, undergarments, etc.

Sra. Ydalina L. sells ice cream and soft drinks. She will invest her money in the purchase of soda, ice cream, beer, etc.; Sra. Amalia G. sells milk and wants to invest her moeny in the purchase of food for her dairy cows.

Sras. Ricarda G., Clemencia Martínez, and Ángela R. sell food for breakfast, lunch and snacks. These women will each invest in the purhcase of ingredients for the preparation of their meals: noodles, milk, flour, salt, meat, cooking oil, etc.

Sra. Graciela sells produce, Sras. Mirna S., Irene A. and Nélida M. each own their own shop where they sell staples like sugar, canned goods, flour, noodles, fruit and vegetables; they will all invest their loan funds in the purchase of merchandise for sale.

Aida G. sells novelty goods. She will invest her money in the purchase of different articles for sale, such as picture frames, makeup, school supplies, etc., and Maria G., who is a midwife, will invest her money in the purchase of supplies such as towels, disposable gloves and medications.

In the photograph the women are shown, accompanied by two American visitors who came to Paraguay several months ago to work with Funcacion Paraguay working on different projects, including Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva volunteer.

El contacto para el inicio del presente comité fue una mujer que pertenecía a otro comité de la misma zona y le informó sobre el programa a la señora Agustina S., luego de eso, ella organizó a sus vecinas para formar el comité.

Limpia A., Mónica A., Agustina S. y Mirtha G., se dedican a la venta de ropas y lencería, ellas invertirán su dinero en la compra de mercaderías como remeras, pantalones, bermudas, faldas, ropa interior, etc.

la señora Ydalina L. se dedica a la venta de helados y bebida, ella invertirá su dinero en la compra de gaseosa, helados, cerveza, etc.; la señora Amalia G. se dedica en la venta de leche y desea invertir su dinero en la compra de alimentos para sus vacas.

Las señoras Ricarda G., Clemencia Martínez, y Ángela R. se dedican a la venta de comidas para desayunos, almuerzos y comidas rápidas, estas señoras invertirán cada una en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de sus comidas como: fideos, leche, harina, sal, carne, aceite, etc

. Las señora Graciela V. vende verduras, las señoras Mirna S., Irene A. y Nélida M. poseen cada una sus tiendas en donde venden todo tipo de artículos de primera necesidad como azúcar, productos enlatados, harina, fideos, frutas y verduras; las mismas invertirán sus créditos para la compra de mercaderías.

Aida G. se dedicará a la venta de artículos de mercería, ella invertirá su dinero en la compra de diferentes artículos para la venta como porta retratos, maquillaje, artículos escolares, etc. y Maria G. quien es partera, invertirá su dinero en la compra de utensilios como toallas, guantes desechables y medicamentos.

En la foto aparecen las señoras, acompañadas de dos pasantes estadounidenses que vinieron a Paraguay hace unos meses atrás para realizar una pasantía en Fundación Paraguaya trabajando en diferentes proyectos, entre ellos Kiva.

loans.use: Purchase of milk, sugar, tea, flour, soft drinks, dairy products, t-shirts, pants, skirts, blouses, undergarments, picture frames, cleaning products, etc.

loans.name: Total 2083(A) Group

texts.en:
Alice is 32 years old and married with six children. She also cares for three dependants. Her business offers tailoring services. She wants to use the extra profits she earns to start a beauty salon and secure a plot of land. Pheobe sells fresh foods. Florence owns a small bar and wants to use the loan to purchase more furniture. Agnes sells charcoal and wants to increase her inventory.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy new sewing machines and improve the other businesses

loans.name: Oniyemofe

texts.en: Mrs. R. Oniyemofe is 47 years old, married, has four children and hails from the town of Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. Since 2005, she has made a living running a beauty parlor and selling grooming supplies. She has been a LAPO client for the last two years, and has applied for a new loan to buy equipment and supplies for her small business.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for a beauty parlor

loans.name: Total 2083(B) Group

texts.en:
Margret is 30 years old and married with three children. She sells charcoal for a living. She wants to use the extra business profits to renovate her house.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand the business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria E. is 30 years old, married and has four children. She lives in the town of Igbede in Lagos State, Nigeria, where she supports her family by selling clothing, renting out videos and CDs, and designing fashions. She has learned these trades over the past two years, but has been in business for herself since 1999. She has been a LAPO client for two years, and has applied for a new loan of $450 to buy more clothing to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Total 2083(C) Group

texts.en:
Hadijah sells fresh foods. Resty and Aisha each have retail shop businesses. They will use this loan to increase their inventory. Annet sells charcoal. She intends to use the extra profits she generates to buy a piece of land. She will also pay school fees for her children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To re-invest in their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Total 2083(D) Group

texts.en:
Betty N. is 40 years old and married with four children. She runs a retail shop. With the business profits she earns, she wants to start a beauty salon business. Oliver sells fresh foods. Justine wants to use this loan to buy a fridge for her restaurant. Mary and Betty N. own beauty salons.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Selminaz

texts.en: Ms. Selminaz is a low-income, vulnerable woman (her son is pictured). She is married with seven children and lives in the Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Selminaz rents a small shop in the local bazaar of Saatli town and sells food. Her children help her. The business is very successful and needs some investments to increase the daily turnover. But Selminaz has no collateral to apply to the commercial banks. That's why she applied to the Normicro Saatli branch for a $600 loan. This credit could let her to buy and sell a bigger amount of goods and to provide better for the necessities of life for her children.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Aliadas Al Trabajo Group

texts.es:
This committee was originally founded by 5 women that knew each other through the committee program of the Paraguayan Foundation and decided to form their own group. They are now in their third cycle of loans of the program, and have excellent credit history as they have always paid on time.

Perla, Pabla, Cornelia, Bernarda, and Silvia each have fast food stands. They sell sandwiches, empanadas, desserts, juice, and sodas among other things. They will use the loan to purchase meats, breads, flour, oil, prepared dough for empanadas, cheese, sodas, vegetables, and fruits, etc.

Mirian, Salvadora, and Liz each own small shops where they sell basic necessities such as bread products, sugar, flour, oil, vegetables, eggs, milk, fruit, and canned goods, etc. They want the loan to buy more merchandise. Veronica has a small butcher shop where she sells meats including chicken and pork. She also sells cold beverages such as sodas, beers, and juice. She will use her part of the loan to buy a new freezer; now that it is summer she has a high demand for cold beverages and the meats will keep better.

Bartola and Rossana dedicate themselves to selling fruits and vegetables. They will use their loans to buy tomatoes, sweet peppers, onions, bananas, apples, oranges, pineapples, and watermelons, etc.

Rosa will buy bracelets, hoop earrings, hair clips, hair products, necklaces, and all types of objects for little girls. Eugenia dedicates herself to recycling and would like to acquire a new cart to transport all the objects she collects to recycle such as plastic bottles, cardboard, and paper, etc.

Silvia has a small restaurant where she sells all types of food. She will use her loan to buy gas, oil, meats, vegetables, noodles, and rice, etc. Martina sells charcoal and wishes to by more charcoal and bags to sell; Mirian sells ice cream and wants to purchase more flavors wholesale. Lastly, Luciana has a small store where she sells various objects such as shampoo, creams, women’s blouses, T-shirts, and pants, etc; she will use the loan to buy more merchandise for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

El presente comité se formó mediante cinco señoras, que se conocían del programa de comité de mujeres de la Fundación Paraguaya y decidieron formar su grupo, el cual ya se encuentra en el tercer ciclo de préstamos del programa, con una calificación muy buena ya que no presentaron ningún atraso de pago en los préstamos anteriores.

Las señoras Perla, Pabla, Cornelia, Bernarda y Silvia poseen puestos de venta de comidas rápidas cada una. Ellas venden sándwiches, empanadas, postres, jugos, gaseosas entre otros, ellas invertirán su crédito en invertirá en la compra de carnes, panes, harina, aceite, disco para empanadas, harina, queso, gaseosas, verduras, frutas, etc.

Las señoras Mirian, Salvadora y Liz poseen despensas cada una en donde comercializan todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad tales como panificados, azúcar, harina, aceite, verduras, huevos, leche, frutas, productos enlatados, etc. Ellas desean el crédito para la compra de mercaderías.

Verónica tiene una pequeña carnicería donde vende carnes y menudencia de vacas, pollo y cerdo, además vende bebidas frías como gaseosas, cervezas y jugos. Ella desea invertir su préstamo en la compra de freezer nuevo, ya que en este verano la demanda de bebidas frías es bastante alta y las carnes se deben conservar mejor.

Bartola y Rossana se dedican a la venta de frutas y verduras, ellas invertirán sus préstamos en la compra de tomates, locotes, cebolla, bananas, manzanas, naranjas, frutas de estación como piñas, sandías, etc.

Rosa invertirá en comprar pulseras, aros anillos, pinzas y gomas para el pelo, cadenas, y todo tipo de bijouteries para niñas; Eugenia se dedica al reciclaje y desea adquirir un carrito nuevo para transportar sus diferentes artículos que recolecta para reciclar, como botellas de plástico, cartones, papeles, etc.

Silvia posee un comedor donde vende todo tipo de comidas por lo que ella desea invertir su crédito en la compra de gas, aceite, carnes, verduras, fideos, arroz, etc. Martina vende carbón y desea comprar más carbón y bolsas para la venta; Mirian vende helados y desea invertirlos en la compra al por mayor de diferentes sabores de helados y Luciana posee una mercería en donde vende artículos varios como shampoo, cremas, blusas para damas, remeras, pantalones, etc. y el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de mercaderías para su negocio.

loans.use: To buy a freezer, milk, sugar, meats, fruits, vegetables, shampoo, creams, blouses, T-shirts, pants, charcoal, plastic items and a cart among other things.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos is a 22 year old man who lives with his parents and two younger brothers. It has been two years since he opened a tire store where he also sells new and used tires.

He hopes that in this business he is able to save and have enough to have a family in the future. Carlos is asking for a loan so that he may buy bigger quantities of used tires in order to fix them to sell. With a greater amount of tires he will increase his sales and better his income.

loans.use: To buy more tires.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with one son, Vasyl. She is a small business owner from Khoost, Ukraine. Nataliya has two market businesses - a clothing sales business and a business selling sweets and candy. She is pictured here with her clothing business. Nataliya started out as an entrepreneur seven years ago. Today she makes about $1200 in monthly net profit.

Nataliya is requesting a loan of $1200 to increase her turnover capital which she will be able to use for both businesses. We believe her natural talent to assess the current trade environments and take advantage of them will stimulate both of her businesses growth, keep them sustainable and profitable, and help Nataliya achieve independence and security in life.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married with one child. She runs a small business selling clothing items at the central market in Ordzhonikidze. Her kiosk always offers a nice variety of merchandise for reasonable prices which attracts a lot of potential customers. Natalya has been in this business for 2 years. Presently, she has about $10,000 in inventory. Her net profit is about $600 a month.

Natalya is hoping to continue growing her venture. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase inventory and help boost her sales. Moreover, she is hoping to open a new vending spot in a different local market. Natalya is constantly looking for new opportunities to improve her trade. We believe her stamina and high energy will help her achieve her goals and repay this current loan on time.

loans.use: To purchase inventory wholesale

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is a young entrepreneur from Melitopol, Ukraine. She has a small women’s shoe sales business at a very good location near the center of the large central market in Melitopol. Svetlana has been in business for about seven years. With the help and advice of relatives and loans from Nadiya Ukaine, her business has done well. In the future, Svetlana would like to expand her business by opening another sales location. Svetlana currently lives with her parents and is able to help them financially as well.

Svetlana has requested a loan of $400 to help purchase a new supply of spring shoe styles for her business. This loan will help increase her profits and help her be prepared for the upcoming change of seasons.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana owns a women’s clothing business located at one of the busy markets in Melitopol, Ukraine. She is an experienced entrepreneur, having been in business for over 15 years, and loves selling clothes. In a normal month, Tatyana makes about $400 in profits which helps make ends meet for her family. Tatyana is married and has two sons. One of her goals for her business is to better the living standards for her family. She would like to use part of her profits to buy some appliances for her home.

Tatyana has requested a short term loan to purchase additional winter clothing to sell in her kiosk. She hopes to maximize her profits and continue developing a stable, profitable business.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is an enterprising business owner from Pavlograd in central Ukraine. She owns two businesses in two very different areas. Much of her time is concentrated on her clothing sales business. She has a kiosk at a busy market in Pavlograd where she sells women’s clothing. As a side venture, Valentina coordinates a transportation business where she rents small buses called marshrutkas and helps people with their transportation needs. Part of this business involves transporting passengers in the summertime to the Black Sea, a popular vacation destination. In the future, Valentina hopes to invest further in her transportation business and buy her own vans rather than having to rent. Valentina is married with two children in their twenties. Her son is married and is soon to have Valentina’s second grandchild.

Valentina has requested a loan of $1200 to help purchase warm winter coats to sell in her clothing business. She has been an excellent client with Nadiya Ukraine in the past. We are happy to continue helping her with her businesses and look forward to seeing how they develop in the future.

loans.use: Purchase cold weather inventory

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is married with two sons. She lives in Khoost, western Ukraine. Victoria sells children’s clothing in the local market. She has been in this trade for 7 years. Currently, she makes about $800 in monthly net profit.

Victoria is very friendly with her customers. She tries to please different tastes and make her clothing affordable for everyone. Today she is requesting a loan of $1,200 to increase the assortment of products she has available. Victoria is planning to use generated income to expand her business. We believe the current loan will have a positive impact on Victoria’s trade profitability, helping to further improve the economic and social situation of her family.

loans.use: To grow her business

loans.name: Comité Ytumí Group

texts.en:
The Ytumí Committee is comprised of 27 working women of the city of Caacupé. They all own and operate small informal businesses which were aided a while back by the program of the Committee of Women Entrepreneurs. Each woman benefited from a mid-size loan of $858.000 Guaranies, about $180 USD.

The first meetings of the committee were held in the house of Rosa O. and it was there that they established ground rules and the central theme of this newly formed organization for women entrepreneurs. All women were to attend the weekly meetings on time for training and to make their loan payments.

The committee decided to undertake a project of helping to eradicate two things in the community. The first was to eliminate the breeding grounds for mosquitoes infected with Dengue, a sometimes fatal disease. At the Fundación Paraguay Office in Caacupe the women cleaned the patio, sidewalks, and streets around the neighborhood.

The second activity is to combat the other sickness that affects not only their neighborhood, but also the rest of the country; crime. Their efforts along with other organizations, demonstrate that there are united, organized people who are prepared to help one another. Gerómina commented that the only way to combat these two evils is to be united and work in groups.

With this loan Gerómina and the other women will continue to expand their businesses. They are working to become a united force in the community who will influence others in their community to have pride for their neighborhood and their country.

loans.use: To buy the premium materials for the production of Chipas, a favorite Paraguayan bread snack made from starch, cheese, vegetable oil, and flour.  Some women need to buy clothes to sell or food merchandise for the grocery stores.  Sugar, meat, yerba, flour, milk, and different types of refreshments, water, beer, and sodas are in high demand in their stores.

loans.name: La Alegría Group

texts.es:
The group named La Alegria (The Happiness) was started in May 2007. One of the members found out about the program Committee of Enterprising Women from a neighbor that had formed her own group. She then contacted her friends and some family members that agreed to become part of her group. The group is comprised of hard-working women that day to day endeavor to earn their daily bread, maintain their homes, and offer their children a good education.

The members dedicate themselves to different lines of work but 11 of them sell chickens. Others sell fruits, eggs, milk, clothes, and prepared foods, etc.

The group La Alegria is comprised of 19 members, all of whom are neighbors. It is located in the city of Ita, in a rural area. They have different fund raising events for the group including lotteries and social gatherings where they sell food. The group has all ready repaid loans from the Foundation and always paid on time. This loan is for $2200 and all the members appear in the picture.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

El Grupo denominado La Alegría tuvo su inicio en el mes de Mayo del Año 2.007, una de las integrantes se enteró del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras por intermedio de una vecina la cual ya había formado su propio grupo. Luego se propuso contactar con sus amigas y algunas de sus familiares, las cuales accedieron en participar dentro del Grupo. El mismo está conformado por señoras trabajadoras que día a día se esfuerzan por ganarse el pan de cada día y colaborar en sus casas y brindar a sus hijos una buena educación.

Las integrantes se dedican a distintas actividades pero once de las integrantes se dedican a la venta de gallinas, otras venden frutas, huevos, leche, ropas, comidas rápidas, etc.

El Grupo La Alegria esta conformado por 19 integrantes de las cuales todas son vecinas, el grupo se encuentra localizado en la Ciudad de Itá en una zona rural. Las mismas realizan distintas actividades para la recaudación de fondos para el grupo como sorteos, polladas, etc.; cabe destacar que el grupo ya ha retirado préstamos de la Fundación con anterioridad y han cumplido de forma excelente con sus pagos. El promedio que desean retirar cada una es de 800.000gs y aparecen todas en la fotografía.

loans.use: To buy chickens, fruits, salon products, beverages, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Comité San Isidro Group

texts.en:
The committee is composed of 15 working women who as a whole are dedicated to the making and selling of Chipas, a local Paraguayan snack. Benita V. was essentially the founder of the group of women and it was in her home that they held the first meetings of the committee.

Of the fifteen women, thirteen are Chipa venders; one owns a meat shop, and the other sells clothes. They are all from the General Díaz neighborhood in the city of Caacupé. One of the great qualities of this committee is their interest in fulfilling the norms and regulations of the program of women entrepreneurs. This is demonstrated through their payment of their monthly loan installments. Also, every weekend they come together and sell their goods at a fair where there is food, raffles, and sports tournaments, among other activities.

The women have received some money to help increase their production and sales. The committee has the great objective of saving enough money together in order to buy play equipment for their children and the children of the community. Their only area for recreation was shut down and they hope to establish swings, slides and some other toys to give their children a place to go to play.

This bright, hardworking group of women entrepreneurs is asking for a loan together to help their businesses grow and flourish. They are mothers who are trying to keep their children in school and who only want to give them a better life. They have long term goals, and even hope to soon give back to the community by establishing a park for children to play. They have created a support group where they rely on one another to make their weekly loan payments. The loan they will receive will be used to buy Chipa ingredients, meat and clothing to sell.

loans.use: Most of the women will use the money to buy the materials to make Chipas, a local Paraguayan bread delicacy, which in comprised of starch, cheese, flour and vegetable oil.  Other women will purchase clothes to sell like shorts, blouses, and shirts, for men women, and children and meat to sell in their butcher shop.

loans.name: Kallé Djivente Ii Kadokor Group

texts.fr:
This project consists in the creation of a chicken coop in the ecovillage of Oussouye, where, despite previous initiatives by the villagers, the supplying of edible chickens is still lacking. Thus to fill this void, we have decided to set up a project of poultry farming. This will enable us to provide for the population and for the different restaurants in the region. This will also allow us to create permanent employment for young boys and girls.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Le présent projet consiste à la création d'un poulailler dans l'écovillage d'Oussouye, qui bien que des initiatives ont été prises par des habitants du village, les besoins en ravitaillement de poulets de chair font toujours défaut. Ce qui fait que pour combler ce manque, nous avons décidé de mettre sur pied un projet d'élevage de poulets. Cela nous permettra de fournir les populations et les différtents restaurants de la zone. Cela permet aussi de créer des emplois fixes pourt des jeunes garçons et filles.

loans.use: Purchase of chicks and poultry feed, poultry farming equipment

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Mai Thị D., 35 years of age, has been a member of the TYM Fund for 7 years. Her main occupation is running a general store business. She started with a modest loan of 60USD for purchasing small amount of goods for her stand, which was on a walkway at the edge of the market. After awhile, she feels comfortable with the weekly repayment routine and gradually increases the loans’ size. Now she has a small store at her own house. The monthly income is 80USD. She would like to take out a loan of 375USD to prepare her store for the coming Tết.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Mai Thị D., 35 tuổi, là thành viên năm thứ 7 của Quỹ Tình thương. Công việc chủ yếu của chị hiện nay là kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa. Khi mới tham gia vào Quỹ chị chỉ dám vay mức 60USD mua một số lượng hàng nhỏ. Nơi bán hàng của chị là vỉa hè ngoài chợ. Sau khi quen với cách hoàn trả tuần và nhận thấy cách hoàn trả này phù hợp với mình chị D. tăng dần mức vốn vay. Đến nay chị D. đã mở được quán bán hàng tạp hóa ngay tại gia đình. Thu nhập hàng tháng từ cửa hàng khoảng 80USD/tháng. Hiện nay chị muốn vay 375USD để mua thêm hàng kinh doanh trong dịp Tết.

loans.use: Buy goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Mai Thị Thành, 53 years old, joins the TYM Fund in 2001. Her husband passed away and she raised two children by herself. The family was in deep hardship. If just relying on small patch of rice paddy, they would not survive. She took out small loans from the Fund to invest in a chè carrying stand. Chè is a Vietnamese favorite sweet dessert. After 10 years, now her both children are grown up and have careers of their own. She changes her work to bamboo weaving so she can work at home. She would like to apply for a loan of 325USD to purchase bamboo.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Mai Thị Thành, 53 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2001. Chồng chị bị bệnh qua đời một mình chị nuôi 2 con, cuộc sống gia đình gặp nhiều khó khăn. Nếu chỉ trông vào mấy sào ruộng thì không thể đủ ăn, chị mạnh dạn vay vốn từ Quỹ Tình thương đầu tư vào mua chè về bán. Trong hơn 10 năm trời chị Thành thức khuya dậy sớm kiếm từng đồng nuôi 2 con ăn học. Đến nay 2 con chị đã trưởng thành và có công ăn việc làm tử tế. Hiện nay đã có tuổi nên chị Thành chọn nghề đan cót để có thể ở nhà ở nhà thường xuyên. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 325USD để mua tre về đan cót tăng thêm thu nhập

loans.use: Buy bamboo to make bamboo mat

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi N., 41 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 1999. During the first several years, she borrowed money to invest in breeding pigs. She and her husband also worked for the brick factory to repay the loan weekly. She always chose the loan that she could be able to repay. Besides using her income from the brick factory to repay the loan weekly, she also used it for family living spendings. For every farrow of pigs, she also got a decent amount of money. As time goes by, her family economy improves. Since the local economy also improves and many households invest in pot plants, she switches to this activity. So far, her greenhouse has more than 200 plants. She wants to borrow 375 USD to buy more fertilizer and pots. She hopes to get 600-800 USD the next time she sells her plants.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị N., 41 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 1999. Những năm đầu tham gia vào Quỹ chị đã vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn còn vợ chồng chị đi làm gạch để lấy tiền trả tiền tuần. Chị luôn chọn các mức vốn phù hợp với khả năng hoàn trả của gia đình. Tiền làm gạch ngoài trả tiền tuần còn dùng chi tiêu cho các khoản tiêu dùng hàng ngày. Mỗi lần bán lứa lợn gia đình lại để ra được một khoản tiền kha khá. Qua các năm kinh tế gia đình chị N. dần dần nâng lên. Khi nhận thấy kinh tế địa phương phát triển, nhiều nhà có nhu cầu chơi cây cảnh, chị N. đã chuyển sang kinh doanh mặt hàng này. Đến nay trong vườn nhà chị đã có hơn 200 cây xanh. Chị N. mong muốn được vay 375USD mua phân bón và làm chậu cây cảnh. Chị hi vọng sẽ thu được 600-800USD trong đợt bán cây sắp tới.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and flowerpots

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs.Tran Thi H., 47 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2000. Her family has 6 members: the parents and 4 children. Her children are all going to schools. Therefore, the family cannot get by if she only does agricutural activies. She thought of investing in business to improve her family’s life. She discussed with her husband and borrowed 60 USD to buy decorative pot plants and they also went fishing to repay the money weekly. She did not get much money from the plants for the first time but she was well encouraged. Because of her hard work and patience, after 7 years joining the Fund, her family owns a greenhouse of approximately 100 plants. Her income from the greenhouse is 150 USD/month. This time, she wants to borrow 500 USD to buy more pot plants and fertilizers.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị H., 47 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2000. Gia đình chị gồm 2 vợ chồng và 4 người con. Nhà đông con lại đều trong độ tuổi ăn học nên nếu chỉ làm ruộng thì không thể đủ ăn. Chị H. nghĩ để thay đổi cuộc sống phải mạnh dạn đầu tư làm kinh tế. Chị bàn với chồng và xin vay 60USD đầu tư vào mua giống cây cảnh còn vợ chồng chị đi bắt cá để trả tiền tuần. Số tiền thu được khi bán lứa cây đầu tiên không nhiều nhưng là một sự khích lệ lớn đối với chị H.. Với tính kiên trì chịu khó, sau 7 năm tham gia vào Quỹ, đến nay gia đình chị đã có vườn cây cảnh với gần 100 cây. Thu nhập từ vườn cây là 150USD/tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị H. xin tiếp tục vay 500USD để đầu tư mua cây giống và phân bón.

loans.use: Buy pot plant and fertilizer

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris is a craftswomen and makes clothing, comforters and sheets. She is also employed at an insurance agency. These two activities combine to be her primary source of income, which she uses to help her daughter who is beginning studies at the local state university. She lives in the Achachicala District within the city of La Paz. The loan she is requesting will be used to purchase a new sewing machine to help increase her production level thereby generating an increase in her family’s income. This is the fourth loan with Impro. Her excellent repayment history facilitates in granting her a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Garcia, Kiva volunteer.

Doris es artesana y confecciona prendas de vestir, edredones y sabanas; también trabaja como empleada eventual en una empresa de seguros. Estas dos actividades son sus fuentes de ingresos principales con los que cubre la manutención de su hija que esta entrando a estudiar a la universidad estatal; vive en la Zona Achachicala de la ciudad de La Paz. El crédito que ahora solicita será destinado a la compra de una maquina recta, misma que le ayudara a mejorar su producción en costuras y generara mayores ingresos familiares. Es el cuarto crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago que demostró le faculta para otorgarle otro préstamo.

loans.use:
Purchase of a sewing machine for her business

Compra de maquina de coser para su negocio

loans.name: Aydee Ambrosia's Group

texts.en:
Aydee, Domenica, and Santa have been members of the community bank “Sr. de Luren” for between two and five years. During that time, they have learned about responsibility, saving, and punctuality. In addition, they have learned how to depend on themselves and develop enduring relationships with other bank members.

Aydee is 33 years old and has a seven year old daughter. She owns a bakery that was started by her mother. She has been running the business since her mother retired four years ago. In addition, Aydee is studying to be a lawyer.

Domenica is 33 and has a five year old son. She knits items such as hats and gloves that she sends to Lima to be exported. She knits all of her products by hand. Domenica has been knitting for five years, before that she sold firewood. She is much happier now.

Santa is 32 and has two children. She moved to Ayacucho nine years ago from the jungle region of Peru and started a business selling food staples such as rice, sugar, and oil. Since that time, and especially since joining the community bank, her business has grown considerably.

Aydee, Domenica, and Santa need loans of 1200, 600, and 400 soles respectively (3 soles = $1, which they will invest in buying materials to expand their business. These include flour, yarn, wool, sugar, and butter. The loan helps them buy in larger quantities and receive lower prices.

The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving, and each associate has an interest earning savings account. Aydee is saving to take her graduation exam. Domenica and Santa are saving to buy land and build a house. Their respective dreams are to become a lawyer and professional, own a home, and to be able to run their business from their home.

loans.use: to invest in buying materials to expand their businesses.  These items include flour, yarn, wool, sugar, and butter.  The loan helps them buy in larger quantities and receive lower prices.

loans.name: Marin

texts.es:
Marin Carlos is a public city transportation driver in El Alto - La Paz. He uses his car for work as well as to support his 4 children and wife. He lives in the Pasankeri area of La Paz. He needs the loan to buy parts for his car to keep it in good condition and thus to continue to be able to cover household expenses and his children's education. This will be his first loan with Impro. The assessment done on him, his experience, and his desire to succeed all qualify him for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Marin Carlos, es chofer de transporte publico Inter ciudad El Alto – La Paz; tiene su vehiculo que le sirve de herramienta de trabajo y con que cubre la manutención de sus 4 hijos y esposa; vive en la Zona Pasankeri de la Ciudad de La Paz. El crédito requerido será utilizado para comprar repuestos para su vehiculo y así mantenerlo en mejores condiciones para seguir cubriendo sus gastos familiares y la educación de sus hijos. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle el préstamo solicitado, en vista de su experiencia y sus deseos de superación.

loans.use: To buy parts for his car

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es:
Filomena is a dairy farmer and small farmer of potatoes and chuno (a processed black potato with a different flavor). These are her main sources of income. She lives with her youngest son who is 19 years old and helps her take care of the cows and do the field work. She lives in the community of Ninachiri - Laja (located an hour and a half from La Paz). She needs the loan to buy a mid-quality milking cow in order to sell more milk to PIL Andina (a dairy processing plant). This will be her second loan with Impro. Her good credit history facilitates the process to receiving another loan. With the previous loan, she was able to buy another dairy cow with which she increased her monthly income.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Filomena es productora de leche y pequeña agricultora de papa y chuño (papa procesada que toma un color negro y tiene otro sabor diferente). Estas actividades constituyen sus principales fuentes de ingresos; ella vive con su hijo menor de 19 años quien que le ayuda con el cuidados de las vacas y el trabajo del campo. Vive en la Comunidad de Ninachiri – Laja (Ubicado a una hora y media de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito requiere para comprar una vaca lechera de mediana calidad, para incrementar la cantidad de leche que vende a PIL Andina (Planta procesadora de productos lácteos). Es el segundo crédito con Impro, el buen historial del crédito anterior le faculta para atorgarlo otro préstamo. Con el préstamo anterior ella pudo comprar otra vaca lechera y lograr un incremento en su ingreso mensual.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Laura

texts.es:
Laura lives at home with her mother on Pioneros de Rochadle street in the Alto San Pedro area of La Paz. She makes pieces of artwork made of plaster and sells the finished products at the Alasitas market, but also to bookstores. The loan she is asking for is to buy material to be able to produce more artwork to take advantage of the Alasitas fair which begins January 24 and ends at the end of February. She has not worked with Impro in the past but she qualifies to apply for a loan as a microentrepreneur with experience in her field.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Laura vive en casa de su madre en la calle Pioneros de Rochadle de la zona de Alto San Pedro de la Ciudad de La Paz con su mamá; la actividad que realiza es la elaboración de artesanía en yeso y vende estos productos terminados en la feria de Alasitas, pero también acomoda en las librerías. El crédito que solicita es para la compra de material y poder elaborar en mayor cantidad y aprovechar la feria de Alasitas, que comienza el 24 de Enero y termina a fin de Febrero. No tiene antecedente con Impro pero califica para acceder a un crédito en su condición de microempresaria con experiencia en su ramo.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her plaster crafts

loans.name: Jhonny

texts.es:
Jhonny rents a place with his wife and daughter on Buenos Aires street in La Paz. He earns wages as a transporter, and his wife works cleaning homes. The loan he is asking for will be used to buy materials to make costumes for carnival festivities since it is holiday time. They want to take advantage of this time which only occurs once a year to earn a little extra money making costumes. His credit history shows him to be a good client which qualifies him to apply for a new loan. He completely paid off his previous loan.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Jhonny vive en alquiler con su esposa y su hija en la calle Buenos Aires de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como transportista asalariado y su esposa trabaja realizando limpieza de una casa como trabajadora del hogar. El crédito que solicita es para comprar material ya que como es fecha festiva confeccionaran disfraces para las fiestas de carnaval. De esta manera ellos quieren aprovechar esta ocasión que se presenta una vez al año para ganar un poco más de dinero con esta actividad de confección de disfraces. Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito. El préstamo anterior fue cancelado en su totalidad.

loans.use: To buy fabric, buttons, etc for making costumes

loans.name: Abraham

texts.es:
Abraham lives in a store rented under an *anticretico contract. The store is on Canonigo Ayllon street in the Tembladerani area of La Paz. He works selling office/school supplies and also has photocopiers with which he generates revenue to cover maintanence. He is asking for the loan to buy supplies since it is back-to-school time. He has no previous history with Impro but he qualifies to apply for a loan. *anticretico- contract in Bolivia in which the renter pays the landlord a fixed sum at the beginning in lieu of montly rent

Translated by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Abraham vive en anticrético en una tienda en la calle Canónigo Ayllón de la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz; se dedica a la venta de material de escritorio y también tiene fotocopiadoras con las cuales genera sus ingresos para su manutención. El crédito que solicita es para comprar material ya que es la temporada de inicio de clases en los colegios y escuelas. No tiene antecedente con Impro pero califica para acceder a un préstamo.

loans.use: To buy office/school supplies (notebooks, pencils, pens, etc)

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Ms Rosa M. lives in her own home in the Miraflores zone in the city of La Paz. This property was ceded to her by the municipal government as compensation for the collapse of her property in Cotahuma in 1999. Ms Rosa is an attendant at a public restroom. The loan she solicits will help finalize legal documentation for her house and the building of a cement moulding for her patio. Rosa has already obtained and completely repaid loans from Kiva. This is the seventh time she solicits a loan, and the achieved socioeconomic analysis favorably qualifies her and allows her to solicit another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa M. vive en casa propia en la zona de Miraflores de la Ciudad de La Paz, propiedad que fue cedida por el gobierno municipal como compensación por el derrumbe de su propiedad en Cotahuma el año 1999. La señora Rosa atiende un mingitorio público. El crédito solicitado será destinado a la conclusión de la legalización de los documentos de la vivienda, así como el vaciado del patio con cemento. Rosa ya obtuvo un préstamo de Kiva, el cual está completamente pagado. Esta es la séptima ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito.

loans.use: To cover the costs of legal permits and construction

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan lives in his parent's house with his wife and his two children on Alberto Ostria street in the Tembladerani zone in the city of La Paz. He has an automobile that he uses as a taxi, but he also does contractual work for a laundry company. He asks for a loan to improve the appearance and working condition of his automobile since it is his only form of income to sustain his family. This is the second loan that Juan has solicited through Kiva. He maintains an exemplary payment history. His previous history certifies his exceptional standing and allows him a new loan. He is a client of IMPRO since 2004.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan vive en casa de los padres en la calle Alberto Ostria de la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposa y sus dos hijos; tiene un auto con el cual trabaja como taxista, pero también atiende contratos con una limpieza de ropa. El crédito que solicita es para mejorar la apariencia de su auto y ponerlo en mejores condiciones ya que es su único medio para generar ingresos y mantener a su familia. Esta es la segunda vez que Juan solicita un crédito a través de la línea Kiva. Su historial de pago ha sido impecable. Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito. Es cliente de IMPRO desde el año 2004.

loans.use: The maintenance of his taxi

loans.name: Comité Las Amigas Group

texts.en:
The committee is comprised of 22 working women of the Kennedy neighborhood who all own small informal businesses. Together they received some money, about $150 USD for each group member, from a group of businesswomen. There are very demanding standards for this group of Caacupé women. They are expected to be punctual to every meeting and seminar held. If they are not able to attend the meeting they are to give a reason why, and if it is not sufficient, the woman must pay a monetary fine.

The committee also does many good things for the community including putting on festivities for Children’s Day, in the chapel of the neighborhood. They serviced over 200 children with goodies and sweets, a gift raffle and fun games in 2007. They also organized the cleaning of the blocks in their neighborhood.

This group of women has the objective to demonstrate that in this neighborhood there is an organized and caring group of women who want to see change for the better. They have come up with a budget for their business expenses and are asking for a loan in order to purchases more goods to make Chipas along with groceries and clothes to sell.

loans.use: Some women will buy  material to make Chipas, famous and popular Parguayan snacks which are made from starch, cheese, and vegetable oil.  Other women will purchase clothes to sell, while some need to purchase food and merchandise like food and refreshments.

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona D. is a forty three year old mother of two. For 15 years she has worked giving manicures, pedicures and hairdressing. This knowledge and skill she learned from her mother who also is a very popular hairdresser in the area. Ramona is thankful for her job and for the help of her husband which have allowed them to buy their own house, cover the education bills for their children and maintain the living expenses.

With the loans she received from Fundación Paraguaya, she was able to buy a great variety of dyes, shampoos, facial creams, and more. In the month of December she had such an increase in clientele she had to hire an assistant to make and manage appointments and to help around the salon.

Ramona’s plan for the future as she continues to gain business, is to eventually expand the size of her salon and include selling women’s clothing and jewelry. She has begun to estimate how much exactly it would cost to begin the work. For now, however, she is asking for a loan so that she may purchase more shampoos, conditioners, dye and similar beauty products which will bring more success to her growing business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Myrian

texts.en:
Myrian is a young woman entrepreneur who owns a convenience store. This is thanks to the help of her parents who gave her the initial capital. Apart from running the convenience store, Myrian is also a university student. Both attending school and working at her grocery store has proven to be difficult. However, she enjoys the challenge and has managed to keep up good grades. She was awarded an initial loan from the Fundación Paraguaya and invested and utilized it to purchase more merchandise to sell.

Myrian thought it would be impossible to survive running a convenience store while attending school; however with the help of Fundación Paraguaya she was given a loan to help with the expenses of her store. She knows that in order to be financially secure in the future she must continue with her studies and graduate with a degree. Her plan is to follow the same road as her sisters who now work in business and live in Spain. With this loan, Myrian will continue to increase the size and quality of her store, and will also continue to advance in the business world.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her convenience store.

loans.name: Antonia Tereza

texts.es:
Mrs. Antonia Tereza, being 72 years old, continues to be a very hardworking woman and being very dedicated to her business. Even though she only got one year of schooling she always wanted her 7 children to be better than her. Therefore, she always supported them in their studies. Now, her children are older and don't depend on her any more. Mrs. Antonia is currently living in the Caserío de Piscopampa in the Mache district, Otuzco province in La Libertad state.

She's been selling batteries, aluminum, lamps, firewood, etc. for 40 years. She started at a smaller town called "Campo Bello". She worked there for a while, but then she met her husband and he took her to Caserío de Piscopampa. She continued her business at her new hometown. Now she also purchases and sells fresh cheese. She purchases it at the different farmhouses and then sells them to visitors. She also offers her products at the Trujillo city.

Mrs. Antonia belongs to the "Women at Work" communal bank. She got her first S/. 300.00 loan from this bank, which she used to purchase fresh cheese and batteries. With the new loan of S/.3,000.00, which she will pay back in four months, she will purchase 8 batteries, 7 kilograms of aluminum, 7 petromax lamps and 15 loads of firewood.

Her biggest dream is to have a little cart to transport merchandise to the city of Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Antonia Tereza a sus 72 años de edad sigue siendo una señora muy trabajadora y empeñosa en su negocio. Aunque solo estudió un año siempre quiso que sus 7 hijos fueran mejores que ella, es por eso que siempre les apoyó en sus estudios. Ahora sus hijos ya son mayores y no dependen de ella. Actualmente vive en el Caserío de Piscopampa, distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Hace 40 años que se dedica a la venta de baterías, lámparas, aluminio, leña, etc. Ella empezó en el poblado menor de Campo Bello, ahí estuvo por un tiempo, pero conoció a su esposo y la llevó a vivir al caserío Piscopampa. En este lugar continúo con su negocio. Ahora también se dedica a la compra y venta de cuajada, ella compra en los diferentes caseríos y los vende a los visitantes y también ofrece sus productos en la ciudad de Trujillo. La señora Antonia pertenece al banco comunal “Mujeres de Trabajo”, aquí obtuvo un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 y con ese dinero compró cuajada y baterías. Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, el cual pagará en cuatro meses, comprará 8 baterías, 7 kilogramos de aluminio, 7 lámparas petromax y 15 cargas de leña. Su mayor sueño es tener un carrito para transportar mercadería a la ciudad de Trujillo.

loans.use: Purchase batteries, aluminum, lamps, etc.

loans.name: Eleuteria Isabel

texts.es:
Mrs. Eleuteria Isabel is 50 years old. She finished gradeschool. She has two children and one of them still economically depends on her. She lives in the Mache district, Otuzco province, La Libertad state.

She has a meat, chicken and guinea pig purchasing and selling business. She also sells fresh cheese. Finally she sells cereals like barley and wheat during harvesting season and she owns a mill which she uses to grind and sell these cereals as flour.

She purchases all these products from small producers from the different farmhouses and then sells them wholesale in the Julcán province and at the city of Trujillo. She is a partner of the “Women at Work” communal bank. She got her first loan (of S/.300.00 )from this bank, which she used to buy approximately 20 kilograms of fresh cheese to sell in Trujillo. With this next loan, of S/. 1,900.00, which she will repay in four months, she plans to purchase cattle ( a bull and a cow).

Mrs. Eluteria is also partner of the popular neighborhood eatery “Maria Victoria”.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Eleuteria Isabel tiene 50 años de edad, estudió sólo primaria completa, tiene 2 hijos y uno aún depende de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Liberad. Tiene un negocio de compra y venta de reses, gallinas y cuyes, también se dedica a la compra y venta de cuajada. En tiempo de cosecha vende cereales como trigo y cebada y también cuenta con un molino para moler los cereales y vender harina de los mismos. Todos estos productos los compra a pequeños productores de los diferentes caseríos y luego los vende al por mayor en la provincia de Julcán y en la ciudad de Trujillo. Es socia del banco comunal “Mujeres de Trabajo”, en este banco comunal obtuvo un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 y con este dinero compró aproximadamente 20 kilogramos de cuajada para vender en la ciudad de Trujillo. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,900.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 2 reses (un toro y una vaca). La señora Eleuteria también es socia del comedor popular de su sector, “Maria Victoria”.

loans.use: Purchase cattle ( a cow and a bull)

loans.name: Flor Violeta

texts.es:
Mrs. Flor Violeta is 23 years old. She studied until second grade. She has two children who still economically depend on her. She lives in the Mache district, Otuzco province, La Libertad state.

She owns a business for purchasing and selling cows, guinea pigs, chickens and fresh cheese. She sells cereals, such as wheat and and barley, at the harvesting season. She also makes and sells roof tiles during the summer.

Flor Violeta is getting started on the sale of small animals like guinea pigs, chicken, pigs, turkeys and ducks in Julcán, where she was able to get many clients. She is well known and people request various orders from her.

She got her first loan at the “Women at Work” communal bank. She used her S/. 300.00 loan to purchase some rams. With her new S/. 1,600.00, which she promises to repay in four months, she will purchase two veal, rams and other small animals. Mrs. Flor is also partner in one of the most popular eateries from her neighborhood “Maria Victoria”. Her biggest dream is to own a car so she can home deliver the roof tiles that she makes.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Flor Violeta tiene 23 años de edad, estudió hasta segundo año de secundaria, tiene 2 hijos que aún dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Tiene un negocio de compra y venta de reses, gallinas y cuyes, asimismo compra y vende cuajada (quesillo). En tiempo de cosecha vende cereales como trigo y cebada y también en temporada de verano elabora y vende tejas para el techo de algunas casas. Se inicia en el comercio vendiendo animales menores como cuyes, gallinas, cerdos, pavos y patos en Julcán, lugar donde pudo captar varios clientes, es por eso que es conocida y le hacen pedidos. En el banco comunal “Mujeres de Trabajo” obtuvo un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 y con este dinero compró algunos carneros. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,600.00, el cual pagará en 4 cuotas, comprará 2 terneras, carneros y otros animales menores . La señora Flor también es socia del comedor popular de su sector, “Maria Victoria”. Su mayor sueño es contar con un vehículo para transportar las tejas que elabora para distintos domicilios.

loans.use: Purcahse animals (cattle, veal, etc)

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias (Women United) Group

texts.es:
The group Mujeres Solidarias (Women United) began in November of 2006. The president at that time, Aida Luz R., came personally to the Paraguayan Foundation office located in the city of Itá in order to learn about the requirements necessary to form a group. Aida found out about the program Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Committee of Enterprising Women) in her neighborhood, since a committee had been formed there.

Later Aida spoke with her friends about the service that the Paraguayan Foundation offers through their committee programs, and that is how the group began. Members of the organization work in a variety of areas: selling candy, food, and drinks; making clothes; constructing leather linings for thermoses, etc.

The group Women United is made up of 22 participants who work in different areas in order to earn income for the organization. They participate in weekly meetings and make payments punctually. They all recognize the importance of individual responsibility within the co-op for strengthening the union among members. The average withdrawal from the communal bank has been 1,000,000 Guaranís per group member (approximately $250 dollars each).

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El inicio del Grupo denominado Mujeres Solidarias fue en el mes de Noviembre del 2.006, la presidenta actual en ese tiempo, Aida Luz R., se acercó personalmente a nuestra Oficina ubicada en la Ciudad de Itá para asesorarse sobre los requisitos necesarios para formar su Grupo, ella supo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras en su barrio, ya que en el mismo se había formado un Comité.

Luego comentó con sus amigas el servicio que brinda la Fundación Paraguaya con dicho programa fue así como surgió el grupo. Las integrantes se dedican a distintas actividades como: Venta de Golosinas, comestible, bebidas, confección de ropas, elaboración de forros de cuero para termos, etc.

El Grupo Mujeres Solidarias esta conformado por 22 integrantes, las mismas realizan distintas actividades para la recaudación de fondos para el grupo, participan de las reuniones todas las semanas y realizan sus pagos puntualmente, las mismas reconocen la importancia que tiene la responsabilidad individual dentro del Comité para fortalecer la unión entre ellas. El promedio retirado por las integrantes fue de 1.000.000gs cada una.

loans.use: Purchase of food, drinks, fruit, candy, leather, thread, etc.

loans.name: Paulina Maria

texts.es:
Mrs. Paulina Maria is 44 years old. She left school after fifth grade. She has three children, two of whom still economically depend on her. She lives in the Mache district, Otuzco province, La Libertad state.

She opened up a small store at her house where she sells groceries such as sugar, rice, oil, noodles, etc. She also raises guinnea pigs, sheeps and chicken, which she sells on the Julcán fair on Sundays.
